1054721_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	In determining the amount of our deferred tax assets that we would realize as of December 31, 2010, we determined the largest amount of our deferred tax assets which had a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	The factors we considered in reducing our deferred tax asset allowance included, but were not limited to: i) over the last three years we have generated cumulative pre-tax income of $3.1 million; ii), our analysis of normalized historical book pre-tax income which excluded those items not expected to occur in the future (e.g. realized losses on auction rate securities) indicated cumulative profitability over the same period; iii) we completed the main fixed-price Ford contract in August 2010 thereby eliminating the overrun risk which had previously significantly negatively affected our results; and iv) our assessment of existing customer contracts and agreements and the expected revenue and gross profit that could be reasonably expected therefrom.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	Because we do business in foreign tax jurisdictions, our sales may be subject to other taxes, particularly withholding taxes.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	The tax regulations governing withholding taxes are complex, causing us to have to make assumptions about the appropriate tax treatment.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	Further, we make sales in many jurisdictions across the United States, where tax regulations are increasingly becoming more aggressive and complex.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P27_S3	We must therefore continue to analyze our state tax exposure and determine what the appropriate tax treatments are, and make estimates for sales, franchise, income and other state taxes.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	The following table presents certain financial data as a percentage of total revenue for the periods indicated.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	Our historical operating results are not necessarily indicative of the results for any future period.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	Our revenue is generated from the sale of software, both our own proprietary software and software of third parties that we resell, and the sale of engineering services.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S2	Total revenue increased $32.4 million, or 50%, to $96.8 million in 2010, from $64.4 million in 2009 primarily due to an increase in third-party software sales.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S3	Revenue from customers located outside of North America includes revenue attributable to our foreign operations, as well as software and services delivered to foreign customers from our operations located in North America.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S4	During 2010, our international operations outside of North America consisted principally of operations in Taiwan.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S5	We also have established relatively minor sales and/or support presences in China, India, Japan, Korea, and the United Kingdom.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P29_S6	Revenue from customers located outside of North America increased $12.5 million to $15.9 million in 2010, or 16% of total revenue, from $3.4 million, or 5% of total revenue, in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems in the Asia Pacific ( APAC ) region in 2010 compared to none in the prior year, given that we entered into the distribution agreement initially in November 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	To a lesser extent, international growth in 2010 was attributable to an increase in engineering service revenue in Asia and Europe.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Software revenue Software revenue consists of sales of third-party software and revenue from our own proprietary software products, which include software license sales, royalties from our software products, sales of our software development kits, support and maintenance revenue, as well as royalties from certain engineering service contracts.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	Software revenue for 2010 and 2009 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	The vast majority of our third-party software revenue is comprised of sales of Microsoft General Embedded operating systems ( General Embedded OS ) in North America and sales of Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems ( Windows Mobile OS ) on a worldwide basis.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S3	Third-party software sales increased $31.5 million, or 97%, in 2010 as compared to the prior year.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S4	Primarily this increase is due to 55% higher sales volumes from our top ten General Embedded OS customers, as well as an approximate 29% increase in average sales volumes from our smaller General Embedded OS customers to pre-2009 levels.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S5	We attribute much of this sales volume increase to the improved economic conditions in the United States, as well as a change made by Microsoft which now directs sales of certain Microsoft products through their embedded channel rather than other Microsoft channels.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S6	Sales of General Embedded OS increased $20.8 million, or 70%, to $50.5 million in 2010, from $29.7 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S7	Sales of Windows Mobile OS were $10.2 million for 2010, compared to none in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S8	Proprietary software revenue increased $1.0 million, or 24%, in 2010 as compared to 2009 due primarily to growth in TestQuest product revenue driven by two significant licensing sales closed in the fourth quarter related to China Mobile Communications Corporation ( CMCC ).
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S9	These sales benefited the fourth quarter by $723,000 and were related to CMCC s initiative to monitor their network services by deploying handsets into 31 provinces across China, using our TestQuest Countdown product to test the deployed handsets.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S10	While additional opportunities exist for selling TestQuest products to other mobile operators as a network monitoring solution, the timing of such sales are difficult to predict, and will likely happen infrequently, if at all.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S11	Further, it should be noted that these TestQuest sales in the fourth quarter of 2010 are separate from our previously announced Handset Certification Platform, in which mobile operators utilize our TestQuest Countdown product to test pre-production handsets.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S12	Total Test Quest licensing revenue increased $322,000 in 2010, compared to the prior year, while total TestQuest revenue, including TestQuest PCS revenue, increased by $866,000 in 2010 compared to the prior year.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P31_S13	Texas Instruments OMAP-related and Qualcomm Snapdragon-related revenue also contributed to the growth.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	Service revenue Service revenue for 2010 and 2009 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	Service revenue decreased nominally by $134,000, or 0%, in 2010 as compared to 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	North American service revenue declined $1.8 million to $25.0 million in 2010, from $26.8 million in 2009, primarily due to a $2.0 million decrease in service revenue related to Ford, offset by revenue increases related to other customers.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P33_S2	Ford continued to be our largest engineering services customer in 2010, representing 47% of service revenue, compared to 53% of service revenue in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P33_S3	Ford contributed $12.9 million in service revenue in 2010 compared to $14.9 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	We began working with Ford in the second quarter of 2008 assisting in the development of their next generation in-dash infotainment offering called MyFord Touch.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	Our initial project with Ford ran from the second quarter of 2008 and was completed in the third quarter of 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S2	During the initial project we provided hardware design and implementation, platform level software development, application level software development, quality assurance services and systems integration services.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S3	Total service revenue recognized on the initial project was $22.0 million.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S4	The contract underlying the initial project began as a time and material contract, and in the second quarter of 2009 it was converted to a fixed-price contract.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S5	Since approximately the completion of the initial project, we have performed all services for Ford under a new time and materials contract which contains certain minimum commitments in terms of the number of resources we provide Ford, and amounts they pay us.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S6	This new time and materials contract, called the Ford Telematics Competency Center ( FCC ), commits a certain number of engineering services personnel to Ford for a set fee.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S7	The FCC represented $3.6 million of the 2010 Ford-related service revenue.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S8	Since we completed the initial project, the number of engineers working on Ford programs has declined under the FCC because we are now primarily focused on developing and integrating new user applications for the MyFord Touch, enhancing existing applications and customizing the MyFord Touch platform for additional vehicle models.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S9	In February 2011, we agreed with Ford, under a contract amendment, to expand the size of the FCC and to extend the term of the agreement to December 31, 2011.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S10	Under this new agreement, we expect the FCC to generate $9.3 million in revenue in 2011.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S11	Service revenue from the APAC region increased $1.4 million, or 170%, to $2.4 million in 2010 from $1.0 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S12	The higher revenue was primarily driven by several projects with new customers in Japan as well as higher revenue in the rest of the APAC region due to the improved economy there compared to 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P34_S13	Growth in the APAC region coupled with growth in Europe and growth in North America outside of Ford roughly offset the decline in Ford service revenue.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	Gross profit and gross margin Cost of revenue related to software revenue consists primarily of the cost of third-party software as well as the amortization of certain intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	Cost of revenue related to service revenue consists primarily of salaries and benefits, contractor costs and re-billable expenses, plus related facilities and depreciation costs.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	Gross profit on the sale of third-party software products was also positively affected by rebate credits of $804,000 in 2010 and $709,000 in 2009 from Microsoft which we earned through the achievement of defined objectives.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	The following table outlines software, services and total gross profit (dollars in thousands): Software gross profit and gross margin Software gross profit increased by $5.1 million, or 59%, in 2010, as compared to 2009, while software gross margin decreased by four percentage points.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	The increase in software gross profit, and the decline in gross margin, was primarily due to an increase in sales of our third-party software in 2010, primarily Microsoft General Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, on which we realize much lower gross margins , and resulting gross profit, than we realize with respect to our proprietary software.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P36_S2	Our third-party software margin was 15% in 2010, and 16% in 2009, compared to our proprietary software gross margin of 88% in 2010, and 86% in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P36_S3	We currently expect third-party software sales to continue to be a significant percentage of our software revenue, and, therefore, our overall software gross margin will likely remain relatively low in the foreseeable future.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	Service gross profit and gross margin Service gross profit increased by $2.0 million, or 42%, in 2010 as compared to 2009, while service gross margin increased by seven percentage points to 24% in 2010, from 17% in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	The increase in service gross profit and gross margin was primarily due to overruns on the Ford project which negatively affected 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	As the Ford project was accounted for under the percentage of completion method, the project overruns negatively affected the amount of revenue we recognized which, in turn, negatively affected our realized billing rate, gross profit, and gross margins.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	Operating expenses Selling, general and administrative Selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of salaries and related benefits, commissions and bonuses for our sales personnel and related facilities and depreciation costs, as well as professional services fees (e.g., consulting, legal and audit).
1054721_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $838,000, or 7%, to $12.9 million in 2010, from $12.0 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	Selling, general and administrative expenses represented 13% of our total revenue in 2010 compared to 18% of revenue in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	2009 benefited from the reversal of our securities class action legal reserve in the third quarter of 2009 in the amount of $534,000.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	Excluding the impact of this reversal, selling, general and administrative expense increased in 2010 by $304,000, or 3%, from $12.5 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P39_S2	This increase was driven by $220,000 in higher commissions and bonuses attributed to increased revenue, gross profit and net income and $372,000 in higher wage expense primarily due to the hiring of additional sales personnel, offset by decreases in a number of other expense items.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	Research and development Research and development expenses consist primarily of salaries and benefits for software development and quality assurance personnel, contractor and consultant costs, component costs and related facilities and depreciation costs.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P40_S1	Research and development expenses decreased $908,000, or 21%, to $3.4 million in 2010, from $4.3 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P40_S2	Research and development expenses represented 4% of our total revenue in 2010, down from 7% in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P40_S3	The decrease was driven by lower research and development expense associated with our Texas Instruments product initiatives, the majority of which were completed in the first quarter of 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P40_S4	Additionally, we reduced research and development headcount during the year.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Interest and other income (expense), net Other income (expense) consists of interest income on our cash, cash equivalents and investments, gains and losses we may recognize on our investments, as well as gains or losses on foreign exchange transactions.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	Other expense was $504,000 in 2010 compared to other income of $139,000 in 2009, representing a decrease of $643,000.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P41_S2	This increase was primarily due to a $549,000 other-than-temporary impairment loss on the carrying value of our auction rate security investments ( ARS ) that was charged to other expense during 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	Income tax benefit Income tax benefit increased by $2.3 million to $2.4 million in 2010, from $76,000 in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	This increase was due primarily to a $2.6 million tax benefit recognized during the three months ended December 31, 2010 when we reevaluated the net carrying value of our deferred tax assets.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	In prior periods, we had fully reserved our deferred tax assets as we had not been able to determine that it was more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to realize these assets.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P42_S3	Deferred tax assets are evaluated quarterly and our valuation allowance may change in the future based upon our estimate of the probability of future taxable income.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P42_S4	Reductions in our valuation allowance will have a positive effect on our income tax provision while increases in our valuation allowance will have a negative effect.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2010, we had $23.1 million of cash, cash equivalents, short-term and long-term investments and restricted cash, compared to $18.0 million at December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	These balances are net of a valuation allowance recorded against our ARS investments of $378,000 at December 31, 2010, and $686,000 at December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S2	Of the $23.1 million of cash, investments and restricted cash at December 31, 2010, $1.0 million was classified as long-term, most of which relates to $875,000 restricted under the terms of our headquarters operating lease which is also classified as long-term restricted cash, the majority of which will continue to secure that obligation through its expiration in 2014.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S3	Also included in long-term investments is an ARS investment with a par value of $500,000 recorded at estimated fair value of $122,000.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S4	Our working capital was $20.0 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $10.3 million at December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S5	Net cash provided by operating activities was $5.3 million in 2010, primarily attributable to $6.1 million in net income and $2.2 in non-cash expenses, offset in part by a negative change in various working capital line items.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S6	Net cash provided by operating activities was $4.7 million in 2009, primarily attributable to a $3.3 million increase in deferred revenue primarily related to revenue billed but not earned on the Ford project and revenue deferred associated with annual support and maintenance contracts for TestQuest products.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S7	Additionally, $1.8 million of non-cash expenses, and net collections of $1.5 million on our accounts receivable, contributed to net cash provided by operating activities in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P43_S8	These amounts were offset in part by a net loss of $2.7 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	Net cash used by investing activities was $7.7 million in 2010 primarily due to $19.5 million of purchases of short-term investments offset in part by $8.2 million in proceeds from the maturity of short-term investments and $3.8 million in sales of our ARS securities.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	Net cash provided by investing activities was $429,000 in 2009, primarily due to $750,000 in redemptions received on our ARS investments, offset in part by $278,000 in purchases of equipment and furniture.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P44_S2	Financing activities generated cash of $383,000 in 2010 and $10,000 in 2009 as a result of employees exercise of stock options.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P44_S3	We believe that our existing cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and long-term investments will be sufficient to meet our needs for working capital and capital expenditures for at least the next 12 months.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P44_S4	Cash Commitments We have the following future or potential cash commitments:
1054721_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Under the terms of our corporate headquarters lease signed in February 2004, the landlord has the ability to demand payment for cash payments forgiven in 2004 if we default under the lease.
1054721_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	The amount of the forgiven payments for which the landlord can demand repayment was $900,000 at December 31, 2010, and decreases on a straight-line basis over the remaining term of the lease, which expires in 2014.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Bsquare Corporation (the Corporation ) as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 and the related consolidated statements of operations, shareholders equity and cash flows for the years then ended.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Corporation s management.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the auditing standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S5	The Corporation is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S6	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Corporation s internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P0_S7	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall consolidated financial statement presentation.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P1_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P1_S2	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Bsquare Corporation as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	See notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	BSQUARE CORPORATION CONSOLIDATED STATEMENTS OF OPERATIONS (In thousands, except per share amounts) See notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	See notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	See notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	Description of Business and Accounting Policies Description of Business BSQUARE Corporation ( BSQUARE ) was incorporated in Washington State in July 1994.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P6_S1	We and our subsidiaries provide software and engineering services to companies that develop smart devices and to companies that assist others in developing smart devices.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	A smart device is a dedicated purpose computing device that typically has a display, runs an operating system (e.g., Microsoft Windows CE) and may be connected to a network via a wired or wireless connection.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	Examples of smart devices include set-top boxes, home gateways, point-of-sale terminals, kiosks, voting machines, gaming platforms, tablets, handheld data collection devices, personal media players, smart phones and devices targeted at automotive applications.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S2	We primarily focus on smart devices that utilize embedded versions of the Microsoft Windows family of operating systems, specifically Windows CE, Windows XP Embedded and Windows Mobile .
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S3	However, as a result of acquisitions, coupled with our strategic intent to broaden our market focus, we provide software and engineering services to customers developing devices utilizing other operating systems such as Android and Linux.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S4	Basis of Consolidation The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of BSQUARE Corporation and our wholly owned subsidiaries.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S5	All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S6	Reclassification of Previously Issued Financial Statements Fees payable to third-party software suppliers, such as Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ), were previously included in accounts payable and other accrued expenses at December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S7	Such fees payable and accrued expenses have been reclassified into a new balance sheet line-item called Third-party software fees payable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S8	There was no impact on total current liabilities as of December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P7_S9	The Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows for 2009 was also revised to reflect this reclassification (there was no effect on net cash provided by operating activities).
1054721_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	Use of Estimates Preparing financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P8_S1	Examples include provisions for bad debts and income taxes, estimates of progress on professional engineering service arrangements and bonus accruals.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P8_S2	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	Interim results are not necessarily indicative of results for a full year.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	Basic income per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period, and excludes any dilutive effects of common stock equivalent shares, such as options, restricted stock awards, restricted stock units and warrants.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	Restricted stock awards ( RSAs ) are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income per share when underlying restrictions expire and the awards are no longer forfeitable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	Restricted stock units ( RSUs ), which vest over a period of two to four years, are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income per share only when vested.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	Diluted income per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding and common stock equivalent shares outstanding during the period using the treasury stock and if-converted method in the case of stock options and warrants, respectively.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P12_S1	Common stock equivalent shares are excluded from the computation if their effect is anti-dilutive.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P12_S2	Unvested but outstanding RSUs and RSAs which are forfeitable but outstanding are included in the diluted income per share calculation as well.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	The following table presents a reconciliation of the number of shares used in the calculation of basic and diluted income per share (in thousands): Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments We invest our excess cash primarily in highly liquid debt instruments of the U.S. government agencies and municipalities, debt instruments issued by foreign government, corporate commercial paper, money market funds, and corporate debt securities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S1	We classify all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of three months or less from date of purchase as cash equivalents and all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of greater than three months as short-term investments.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S2	Short-term investments consist entirely of marketable securities which are all classified as available-for-sale securities and are recorded at their estimated fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S3	We determine the appropriate classification of our investments at the time of purchase and reevaluate such designation at each balance sheet date.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S4	We may or may not hold securities with stated maturities greater than 12 months until maturity.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S5	As we view these securities as available to support current operations, we classify securities with maturities beyond 12 months as current assets under the caption short-term investments in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P13_S6	We carry these securities at fair value, and report the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, as a component of stockholders equity, except for unrealized losses determined to be other than temporary which are recorded in other expense.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	Restricted Cash Our restricted cash represents time deposits held at a financial institution as security for an outstanding letter of credit expiring in 2014 related to our corporate headquarters lease obligation.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	Long-term Investments Our long-term investments consist of auction rate securities ( ARS ), which are recorded at their estimated fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P15_S1	Financial Instruments and Concentrations of Risk Financial instruments that potentially subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash equivalents, short-term investments, and accounts receivable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P15_S2	Cash equivalents and short-term investments consist primarily of highly liquid debt instruments of the U.S. government agencies and municipalities, debt instruments issued by foreign government, corporate commercial paper, money market funds, and corporate debt securities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P15_S3	The carrying value of these instruments approximates fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts We record accounts receivable at the invoiced amount net of an estimated allowance for doubtful accounts to reserve for potentially uncollectible receivables.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	We review customers which are past due to identify specific customers with known disputes or collectability issues.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P16_S2	In determining the amount of the reserve, we make judgments about the creditworthiness of significant customers based on ongoing credit evaluations.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P16_S3	We account for property and equipment at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	We compute depreciation using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets, generally three years.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the lease term or estimated useful lives, ranging from 2 to 10 years.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	Maintenance and repairs costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	When assets are retired or otherwise disposed of, gains or losses are included in the statement of operations.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	When facts and circumstances indicate that the value of long-lived assets may be impaired, an evaluation of recoverability is performed by comparing the carrying value of the asset to projected undiscounted future cash flows.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P20_S1	Upon indication that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable, we recognize an impairment loss as a charge against current operations based on the difference between the carrying value of the asset and its fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	Intangible Assets Intangible assets were recorded as a result of asset acquisitions and are stated at estimated fair value at the time of acquisition less accumulated amortization.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	Amortization is provided on the straight-line method over estimated useful lives as follows:
1054721_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	4 years We review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P23_S1	We measure recoverability of these assets by comparing the carrying amounts to the future undiscounted cash flows the assets are expected to generate.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	If intangible assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment to be recognized equals the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair market value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	We record all fees payable and accrued liabilities related to the sale of third-party software, such as Microsoft general embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, as third-party software fees payable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	Software Development Costs No software development costs have been capitalized as the cost has been immaterial.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	Research and Development Research and development costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P26_S2	Advertising Costs All costs of advertising, including cooperative marketing arrangements, are expensed as incurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P26_S3	Advertising expense was $93,000 in 2010 and $149,000 in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	The estimated fair value of stock based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P29_S1	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P29_S2	The BSM model requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P29_S3	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	Incentive Compensation We make certain estimates, judgments and assumptions regarding the likelihood of our attainment, and the level thereof, of bonuses payable under our annual incentive compensation programs.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S1	We accrue bonuses and recognize the resulting expense when the bonus is judged to be reasonably likely to be earned as of year-end and is estimable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S2	The amount accrued, and expense recognized, is the estimated portion of the bonus earned on a year-to-date basis less any amounts previously accrued.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S3	These estimates, judgments and assumptions are made quarterly based on available information and take into consideration our year-to-date actual results and expected results for the remainder of the year.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S4	Because our attainment estimate factors estimated future results, significant judgment is required.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P30_S5	If actual results differ materially from our estimates, the amount of bonus expense recorded in a particular quarter could be significantly over or under estimated.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	Comprehensive Income (Loss) Comprehensive income (loss) refers to net income (loss) and other revenue, expenses, gains and losses that, under generally accepted accounting principles, are recorded as an element of shareholders equity but are excluded from the calculation of net income (loss).
1054721_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	The changes in the components of other comprehensive income (loss) are as follows (in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM8_P31_S2	The components of accumulated other comprehensive loss are as follows (in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	Income Taxes We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and certain foreign jurisdictions.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P32_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	under which deferred income taxes are provided for on the temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and the tax basis of our assets and liabilities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S1	Our deferred tax assets are measured using currently enacted tax rates that are expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S2	A valuation allowance is established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S3	Beginning in 2002 and through the third quarter of 2010, we maintained a full valuation allowance against our deferred tax assets as we were unable to determine that it was more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to utilize them.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S4	The majority of our deferred tax assets relate to our net operating loss carryforwards.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S5	At December 31, 2010, we had $59.2 million of net operating loss carryforwards which begin to expire in 2022, of which approximately $54.9 million will expire in 2022 and 2023.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P33_S6	Utilization of these carryforwards may be subject to an annual limitation due to Section 382 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code which restricts the ability of a corporation that undergoes an ownership change to use its net operating loss carryforwards.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	An ownership change occurs if greater than five percent shareholders of an issuer s outstanding common stock collectively increase their ownership percentage by more than 50 percentage points over a rolling three-year period.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	We have performed analysis of possible ownership changes in the past which included consideration of a third-party study, and do not believe that an ownership change of more than 50 percentage points has occurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009 we utilized approximately $5.6 million and $0, respectively, of net operating losses to offset taxable income.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	In the fourth quarter of 2010, we determined that it was more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to utilize a portion of our net operating losses and, as a result, we recorded a $2.6 million reduction in our deferred tax asset valuation allowance and corresponding income tax benefit.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P35_S2	In determining the amount of our net operating losses that we would realize as of December 31, 2010, we determined the largest amount of our deferred tax assets which had a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P35_S3	The factors we considered in reducing our deferred tax asset allowance included, but were not limited to: i) over the last three years we have generated cumulative pre-tax income of $3.1 million; ii), our analysis of normalized historical financial statement book pre-tax income which excluded those items not expected to occur in the future (e.g. realized losses on auction rate securities) indicated cumulative profitability over the same period; iii) we completed the main fixed-price Ford contract in August 2010 thereby eliminating the overrun risk which had previously significantly negatively affected our results; and iv) our assessment of existing customer contracts and agreements and the expected revenue and gross profit that could be reasonably expected therefrom.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	Interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions may be classified in the financial statements as either income taxes or interest and another expense classification.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	We have elected to classify interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions as income tax expense.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P36_S2	There are no interest and penalties included in income tax benefit in 2010 or 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	The functional currency of foreign subsidiaries is the local currency.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	Accordingly, assets and liabilities are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P37_S2	Resulting translation adjustments are included in Accumulated other comprehensive loss, a separate component of shareholders equity.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	The net gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are recorded in the period incurred and were not significant for any of the periods presented.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	been rendered; the selling price is fixed or determinable; and collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	Contracts and customer purchase orders are generally used to determine the existence of an arrangement.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	Shipping documents and time records are generally used to verify delivery.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S2	We assess whether the selling price is fixed or determinable based on the contract and/or customer purchase order and payment terms associated with the transaction and whether the sales price is subject to refund or adjustment.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S3	We assess collectability based primarily on the creditworthiness of the customer as determined by credit checks and analysis, as well as the customer s payment history.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S4	Periodically, we will begin work on engineering service engagements prior to having a signed contract and, in some cases, the contract is signed in a quarter after which service delivery costs are incurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S5	We do not defer costs associated with these uncontracted engagements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P40_S6	We recognize software revenue upon shipment provided that no significant obligations remain on our part, substantive acceptance conditions, if any, have been met and the other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	Service revenue from time and materials contracts, and training service agreements, is recognized as services are performed.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P41_S1	Fixed-price service agreements, and certain time and materials service agreements with capped fee structures, are accounted for using the percentage-of-completion method.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P41_S2	We use the percentage-of-completion method of accounting because it is the most accurate method to recognize revenue based on the nature and scope of these engineering service contracts; it is a better measure of periodic income results than other methods and it better matches revenue recognized with the costs incurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P41_S3	Percentage of completion is measured based primarily on input measures such as hours incurred to date compared to total estimated hours to complete, with consideration given to output measures, such as contract milestones, when applicable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P41_S4	Significant judgment is required when estimating total hours and progress to completion on these arrangements which determines the amount of revenue we recognize as well as whether a loss is recognized if one is expected to be incurred for the remainder of the project.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	Revisions to hour and cost estimates are incorporated in the period in which the facts that give rise to the revision become known.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	We also enter into arrangements in which a customer purchases a combination of software licenses, engineering services and PCS.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P42_S2	As a result, contract interpretation is sometimes required to determine the appropriate accounting, including how the price should be allocated among the deliverable elements if there are multiple elements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	PCS may include rights to upgrades, when and if available, telephone support, updates, and enhancements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	When VSOE of fair value exists for all elements in a multiple element arrangement, revenue is allocated to each element based on the relative fair value of each of the elements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	VSOE of fair value is established by the price charged when the same element is sold separately.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	Accordingly, the judgments involved in assessing the fair values of various elements of an agreement can impact the recognition of revenue in each period.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P45_S2	Changes in the allocation of the sales price between deliverables might impact the timing of revenue recognition, but would not change the total revenue recognized on the contract.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	When elements such as software and engineering services are contained in a single arrangement, or in related arrangements with the same customer, we allocate revenue to each element based on its relative fair value, provided that such element meets the criteria for treatment as a separate unit of accounting.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	In the absence of fair value for a delivered element, revenue is first allocated to the fair value of the undelivered elements and then allocated to the residual delivered elements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P46_S2	In the absence of fair value for an undelivered element, the arrangement is accounted for as a single unit of accounting, resulting in a delay of revenue recognition for the delivered elements until the undelivered elements are fulfilled.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P46_S3	As a result, contract interpretations and assessments of fair value are sometimes required to determine the appropriate accounting.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	When engineering services and royalties are contained in a single arrangement, we recognize revenue from engineering services as earned in accordance with the criteria above even though the effective rate per hour may be lower than typical because the customer is contractually obligated to pay royalties on their device shipments.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	We recognize royalty revenue, classified as software revenue, when the royalty report from the customer is received or when such royalties are contractually guaranteed and the revenue recognition criteria are met, particularly that collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	In January 2010, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued ASU 2010-6, Improving Disclosures About Fair Value Measurements ( ASU 2010-6 ), which requires reporting entities to make new disclosures about recurring or nonrecurring fair-value measurements including significant transfers into and out of Level 1 and Level 2 fair-value measurements and information on purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements on a gross basis in the reconciliation of Level 3 fair-value measurements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P48_S1	ASU 2010-6 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2009, except for Level 3 reconciliation disclosures which are effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	The adoption of ASU 2010-6 did not have a material impact on our Consolidated Financial Statement disclosures.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	Cash and Investments Cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments, long-term investments and restricted cash consist of the following (in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	We record our cash equivalents, short-term investments and ARS, at fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	Fair value is an exit price, representing the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P52_S1	As such, fair value is a market-based measurement that should be determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or a liability.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P52_S2	A three-tier fair value hierarchy is established as a basis for considering such assumptions and for inputs used in the valuation methodologies in measuring fair value:
1054721_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	Level 2: Directly or indirectly observable market-based inputs or unobservable inputs used in models or other valuation methodologies.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P55_S1	The inputs require significant management judgment or estimation.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	Our short-term investments consist entirely of marketable securities classified as available for sale.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P56_S1	All short-term investments were valued based on quoted market prices of similar instruments and other significant inputs derived from, or corroborated by, observable market data.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P56_S2	Our long-term investments consist entirely of ARS.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P56_S3	At December 31, 2010 we held $122,000 of ARS represented by one individual investment.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	Historically, ARS have provided liquidity through a Dutch auction process that resets the applicable interest rate at pre-determined intervals every 7 to 49 days.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P57_S1	However, these auctions began to fail in the first quarter of 2008.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P57_S2	The related principal amounts of the ARS will not be accessible until a successful auction occurs, a buyer is found outside of the auction process, the issuer calls the security, or the security matures according to contractual terms.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	Due to the lack of observable market quotes on our ARS, we have estimated their fair values using inputs including the underlying financial condition and credit quality of the issuer, the maturity of the security, and secondary market bid levels of similar and identical securities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P58_S1	Based on these inputs, we estimated the fair value of our ARS to be $122,000 as of December 31, 2010, compared to a par value of $500,000.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	We have classified our ARS as long-term investments as of December 31, 2010 due to our uncertainty as to when these securities will be sold.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	The following table presents a reconciliation for our assets measured and recorded at fair value on a recurring basis, using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3), which entirely consist of ARS (in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009 our cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities primarily consisted of cash, U.S. and foreign government and agency securities, money market funds and other investment grade securities.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	Such amounts are recorded at fair value.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P60_S2	We had $1,000 of unrealized losses on our investments as of December 31, 2010, and $0 at December 31, 2009.

1054721_11_ITEM8_P67_S0	The components of net deferred tax assets consist of the following (in thousands):
1054721_11_ITEM8_P68_S0	The provision for income taxes differs from the amount of income tax determined by applying the applicable U.S. statutory federal income tax rate to pre-tax income, as a result of the following: Beginning in 2002 and through the third quarter of 2010, we maintained a full valuation allowance against our deferred tax assets as we were unable to determine that it was more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income for them to be realized.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P68_S1	In the fourth quarter of 2010, we determined that it was more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to realize a portion of our deferred tax assets, and reduced our valuation allowance accordingly.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P68_S2	At December 31, 2010, we had approximately $61.7 million of federal and state net operating loss carryforwards, and $2.4 million of tax credit carryforwards, which begin to expire in 2022, and of which $54.9 million of the net operating loss carryforwards will expire in 2022 and 2023.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P68_S3	Utilization of these carryforward may be subject to an annual limitation due to Section 382 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code which restricts the ability of a corporation that undergoes an ownership change to use its carryforwards.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P69_S0	Under the applicable tax rules, an ownership change occurs if greater than five percent shareholders of an issuer s outstanding common stock, collectively, increase their ownership percentage by more than 50 percentage points over a rolling three-year period.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P69_S1	We have performed analyses of possible ownership changes in the past, which included consideration of a third-party study, and do not believe that an ownership change of more than 50 percentage points has occurred.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P69_S2	We are no longer subject to U.S. federal tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2007, and with a few immaterial exceptions, we are also no longer subject to U.S. state and local income tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2007.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P70_S0	Our principal commitments consist of obligations outstanding under operating leases, which expire through 2014.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P70_S1	We have lease commitments for office space in Bellevue, Washington; San Diego, California; Longmont, Colorado; Chanhassen, Minnesota; Dallas, Texas; Taipei, Taiwan; Beijing, China and Nishi-Shinjuku, Japan.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P70_S2	We also lease office space in Akron, Ohio on a month-to-month basis.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P70_S3	Subsequent to December 31, 2010, we also signed a one-year lease for office space in Seoul, Korea.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P71_S0	Under the terms of our corporate headquarters lease signed in February 2004, if we default under the lease, the landlord has the ability to demand payment for cash payments forgiven in 2004.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P71_S1	The amount of the forgiven payments for which the landlord can demand repayment was $900,000 at December 31, 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P72_S0	Rent expense was $1.5 million in 2010 and $1.5 million in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P72_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we had $875,000 pledged as collateral for a bank letter of credit under the terms of our headquarters facility lease.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P72_S2	The pledged cash supporting the outstanding letter of credit is recorded as restricted cash.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P73_S0	Operating lease commitments at December 31, 2010 are as follows (in thousands): Legal Proceedings IPO Litigation In Summer and early Fall 2001, four shareholder class action lawsuits were filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against the Company, certain of the Company s current and former officers and directors (the Individual Defendants ), and the underwriters of the Company s initial public offering (the Underwriter Defendants ).
1054721_11_ITEM8_P73_S1	The complaints were consolidated into a single action and a Consolidated Amended Complaint, which was filed on April 19, 2002.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	The operative complaint alleged violations of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P74_S1	The suit purported to be a class action filed on behalf of purchasers of the Company s common stock during the period from October 19, 1999 to December 6, 2000.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P74_S2	The plaintiffs alleged that the Underwriter Defendants agreed to allocate stock in the Company s initial public offering to certain investors in exchange for excessive and undisclosed commissions and agreements by those investors to make additional purchases of stock in the aftermarket at pre-determined prices.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P74_S3	The plaintiffs alleged that the prospectus for the Company s initial public offering was false and misleading in violation of the securities laws because the Company did not disclose these arrangements.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P74_S4	The action sought damages in an unspecified amount.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	On December 5, 2006, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals vacated a decision by the district court granting class certification in six of the coordinated cases, which are intended to serve as test, or focus cases.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	The plaintiffs selected these six cases, which do not include the Company.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S2	On April 6, 2007, the Second Circuit denied a petition for rehearing filed by the plaintiffs, but noted that the plaintiffs could ask the district court to certify more narrow classes than those that were rejected.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S3	The parties in the approximately 300 coordinated cases, including the parties in the Company s case, reached a settlement in early 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S4	As part of the settlement, the insurers for the issuer defendants will make the entire settlement payment on behalf of the issuers, including the Company.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P75_S5	On October 5, 2009, the district court granted final approval of the settlement.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S0	Three objectors filed a petition to the Second Circuit seeking permission to appeal the district court s final approval order on the basis that the settlement class is broader than the class previously rejected by the Second Circuit in its December 5, 2006 order vacating the district court s order certifying classes in the focus cases.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S1	Objectors to the settlement are proceeding with two appeals to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S2	Plaintiffs have moved to dismiss both appeals.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S3	Following the district court s final approval of the settlement, the Company determined that it is unlikely that the Company will be liable for any damages that will not be paid for by the Company s insurance carriers, even if any appeals are successful.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S4	As a result, it was determined that an accrued legal fees liability of $534,000 was no longer probable.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S5	Consequently, this liability was reversed, which resulted in a reduction of selling, general and administrative expense during 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P76_S6	However, due to the inherent uncertainties of litigation, subsequent events could affect the assessment of this liability and this disclosure.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S0	Shareholders Equity Stock Options We have a stock plan (the Plan ) under which stock options may be granted with a fixed exercise price that is typically fair market value on the date of grant.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S1	These options have a term of up to 10 years and vest over a predetermined period, generally four years.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S2	Incentive stock options granted under the Plan may only be granted to our employees, have a term of up to 10 years, and shall be granted with an exercise price equal to the fair market value of our stock on the date of grant.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S3	The Plan also allows for awards of stock appreciation rights, restricted and unrestricted stock awards, and restricted stock units.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S4	The Plan allows for an automatic annual increase in the number of shares reserved for issuance under the Plan.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P77_S5	Such automatic annual increase is in an amount equal to the lesser of: (i) four percent of our outstanding shares at the end of the previous fiscal year, (ii) an amount determined by our Board of Directors, or (iii) 375,000 shares.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P78_S0	The estimated fair value of stock based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P79_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P80_S0	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P80_S1	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P80_S2	The BSM model requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P80_S3	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P81_S0	The fair values of our equity awards, primarily stock option grants, were estimated with the following weighted average assumptions:
1054721_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	The impact on our results of operations of recording stock-based compensation expense for years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009 was as follows (in thousands, except per share amounts):

1054721_11_ITEM8_P86_S0	We issue new shares of common stock upon exercise of stock options.

1054721_11_ITEM8_P92_S0	We have a Profit Sharing and Deferred Compensation Plan ( Profit Sharing Plan ) under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P92_S1	Substantially all full-time employees are eligible to participate in the Profit Sharing Plan.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P92_S2	We typically elect to match the participants contributions to the Profit Sharing Plan up to a certain amount, however we suspended such matching between February 2009 and August 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P92_S3	Participants will receive their share of the value of their investments, and any applicable vested match, upon retirement or termination.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P92_S4	We made matching contributions of $153,000 in 2010 and $51,000 in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P93_S0	All other significant non-cash financing activities are described elsewhere in the financial statements or the notes thereto.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S0	Significant Risk Concentrations Significant Customer The Ford Motor Company ( Ford ) accounted for $12.9 million, or 13%, of total revenue in 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S1	No other customer accounted for 10% or more of total revenue in 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S2	Ford accounted for $14.9 million, or 23%, of total revenue in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S3	No other customer accounted for 10% or more of total revenue in 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S4	No customer accounted for 10% or more of total accounts receivable as of December 31, 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S5	Ford had an accounts receivable balance of $2.4 million, or 26% of total accounts receivable, as of December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P94_S6	No other customer accounted for 10% or more of total accounts receivable as of December 31, 2009.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S0	We have an OEM Distribution Agreement with Microsoft which enables us to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems to our customers in the United States, Canada, the Caribbean (excluding Cuba) and Mexico.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S1	Software sales under this agreement constitute a significant portion of our revenue.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S2	The agreement is typically renewed annually or semi-annually, however there is no automatic renewal provision in the agreement.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S3	This agreement will expire on June 30, 2011.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S4	Microsoft currently offers a rebate program in conjunction with this agreement in which we earn money for achieving certain predefined objectives.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S5	Under this rebate program we earned $804,000 in 2010 and $709,000 in 2009 which is accounted for as a reduction in software cost of revenue.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S6	We signed an additional distribution agreement with Microsoft, in November 2009, which enables us sell Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems and related applications such as Microsoft s Office Mobile on a worldwide basis.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P95_S7	This agreement will expire in November 2011.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P96_S0	Information about Geographic Areas Our chief operating decision-makers (i.e., chief executive officer, and certain of his direct reports) review financial information presented on a consolidated basis, accompanied by disaggregated information about revenues by geographic region for purposes of allocating resources and evaluating financial performance.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P96_S1	There are no segment managers who are held accountable by our chief operating decision-makers, or anyone else, for operations, operating results, and planning for levels or components below the consolidated unit level.
1054721_11_ITEM8_P96_S2	Accordingly, we consider ourselves to be in a single reporting segment and operating unit structure.

1054721_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that the information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In connection with the preparation of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, our management carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our CEO and CFO, as of December 31, 2010, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as such term is defined under Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Based upon this evaluation, our CEO and CFO concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of our financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Internal control over financial reporting is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) promulgated under the Exchange Act and includes those policies and procedures that: (a) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our assets; (b) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that our receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of our management and directors; and (c) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of our assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P1_S3	All internal controls, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Our management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) in Internal Control Integrated Framework .
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on its assessment, our management concluded that, as of December 31, 2010, our internal control over financial reporting was effective.
1054721_11_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during our fourth quarter of 2010 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.

1054721_11_ITEM15_P27_S0	The monthly rate per resource is $***, which shall be pro-rated for partial months based on total calendar days in the month.
1054721_11_ITEM15_P27_S1	The Amendment 3 Fee shall be invoiced monthly at 1/12th the total, less any prorated adjustments required for partial resources in the month, plus any overtime approved of Ford in writing.
1054721_11_ITEM15_P27_S2	As a result of this Amendment, and to approximately account for the value of purchase orders previously issued by Ford, Ford will issue BSQUARE a purchase order in the amount of $***.
1054721_11_ITEM15_P27_S3	This purchase order amount does not include any amounts which may be necessary to fund overtime, rebillable expenses and other expenses incurred by BSQUARE as a result of the Amendment, which will be addressed by the parties through separate changes of scope and purchase orders.
1054721_11_ITEM15_P28_S0	This Amendment may be executed in two counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all of which together shall constitute one instrument.
1054721_11_ITEM15_P28_S1	Except as altered by this Amendment, all terms of SOW 3, as amended, shall remain undisturbed and in full force and effect.

1054721_11_ITEM15_P33_S0	Exhibit 10.19 SCHEDULE TO EXHIBIT 10.19 BSQUARE CORPORATION FORM 10-K FOR THE ANNUAL PERIOD ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2010 Filed herewith as Exhibit 10.19 to the Form 10-K for the annual period ended December 31, 2010, is a copy of the Microsoft OEM Windows Mobile Distribution Agreement between Microsoft Licensing, GP, an affiliate of Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ), and Bsquare Corporation (the Company ), entered into effective as of November 1, 2009, as amended by Amendment No. 1 dated as of September 1, 2010 and Amendment No. 2 dated as of November 1, 2010 (collectively, the Distribution Agreement ).
1054721_11_ITEM15_P33_S1	The Company has also entered into three additional distribution agreements, as amended, with Microsoft that are substantially identical in all material respects to the Distribution Agreement except as to the parties thereto, the dates of execution and other details, including the territories covered (the Additional Agreements ).
1054721_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	this Item regarding compliance by our directors, executive officers and holders of ten percent of a registered class of our equity securities with Section 16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is included in our definitive proxy statement for our 2012 annual meeting of shareholders to be filed with the SEC under the caption Section 16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance and is incorporated herein by this reference.
1054721_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	The remaining information required by this Item is included in our definitive proxy statement for our 2012 annual meeting of shareholders to be filed with the SEC under the caption Corporate Governance and is incorporated herein by this reference.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Factors that might cause or contribute to such differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us, or that we currently deem immaterial, may also impair our business operations.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	If any of the following risks occur, our business, financial condition, operating results, cash flows and the trading price of our common stock could be materially adversely affected.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Microsoft-Related Risk Factors Due to the fact that we have historically provided software and services to customers building devices utilizing Microsoft s Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, as well as the fact that a significant portion of our revenue is derived from the sale of Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, Microsoft has a significant direct and indirect influence on our business.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P1_S3	The following represent several Microsoft-related risk factors which may negatively impact our business and operating results.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	If we do not maintain our OEM and Windows Mobile Distribution Agreements with Microsoft or if Microsoft de-emphasizes or divests itself from these areas of its business, our revenue would decrease and our business would be adversely affected.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	We have OEM Distribution Agreements ( ODA s) for Software Products for Embedded Systems with Microsoft, which enable us to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems to our customers in the United States, Canada, the Caribbean (excluding Cuba), Mexico, the European Union and the European Free Trade Association.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	These ODAs are effective through June 30, 2012.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S3	We have also entered into other ODAs with Microsoft pursuant to which we are licensed to sell Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems to customers in North America, South America, Central America, Japan, Taiwan, Korea, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S4	The ODAs to sell Windows Mobile Operating Systems are effective through June 30, 2012 and July 31, 2012.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S5	We generated $58.4 million and $60.6 million of revenue in 2011 and 2010, respectively, through our sales of Microsoft operating systems and expect this revenue stream to continue in 2012.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S6	If any of the ODAs are terminated by Microsoft (which Microsoft can do unilaterally) or not renewed, or if Microsoft decides to no longer invest in or to divest itself from these areas of its business, our software revenue and resulting gross profit could decrease significantly and our operating results would be negatively impacted.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P2_S7	Future renewals, if any, could be on less favorable terms, which could also negatively impact our business and operating results.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Microsoft can change pricing under the ODAs at any time and recently announced a new pricing change for Windows Embedded operating systems which is currently scheduled to take effect March 1, 2012.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Microsoft could change its pricing structure again and, unless we are able to either pass through price increases to our customers or sign our customers to 12-month purchasing commitments, which lowers the price we pay to Microsoft, our revenue, gross profit and operating results would be negatively impacted.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Further, Microsoft currently offers a rebate program in conjunction with our ODA activities in which we earn money for achieving certain predefined objectives.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S3	If Microsoft were to eliminate or negatively modify the rebate program, our gross profit and operating results would be negatively impacted.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S4	We earned rebate credits from Microsoft of $746,000 and $804,000 in 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Microsoft has audited our records under the ODAs in the past and will likely audit our records again in the future and any negative audit results could result in additional charges and/or the termination of the ODAs.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S6	There are provisions in the ODAs that require us to maintain certain internal records and processes for royalty auditing and other reasons.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P3_S7	Non-compliance with these and other requirements could result in the termination of the ODAs.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Microsoft has concluded an audits of our records pertaining to the ODA in 2009 and 2007, neither of which had material findings.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	It is possible that future audits could result in charges due to any material findings that are found.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	If we do not maintain our favorable relationship with Microsoft, we will have difficulty marketing and selling our software and services and may not receive developer releases of Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	As a result, our revenue and operating results could suffer.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	We maintain a strategic marketing relationship with Microsoft.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	If our relationship with Microsoft deteriorates for any reason, including an increased focus by us on customers building devices utilizing non-Microsoft Embedded or Mobile operating systems, our efforts to market and sell our software and services to OEMs and others could be adversely affected and our business could be harmed.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S4	Microsoft has significant influence over the development plans and buying decisions of OEMs and others utilizing Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems for smart devices and these targeted platforms are a significant focus for us.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S5	Microsoft provides customer referrals to us.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S6	Moreover, Microsoft controls the marketing campaigns related to its operating systems.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P5_S7	Microsoft s marketing activities, including trade shows, direct mail campaigns and print advertising, are important to the continued promotion and market acceptance of Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems and, consequently, to our sale of Windows-based software and services.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	must maintain a favorable relationship with Microsoft to continue to participate in joint marketing activities with them, which includes participating in partner pavilions at trade shows, listing our services on Microsoft s website, and receiving customer referrals.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	In the event that we are unable to continue our joint marketing efforts with Microsoft, or fail to receive referrals from them, we would be required to devote significant additional resources and incur additional expenses to market our software products and services directly to potential customers.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	In addition, we depend on Microsoft for developer releases of new versions of, and upgrades to, Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile software in order to facilitate timely development and delivery of our own software and services.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	If we are unable to maintain our favorable relationship with Microsoft and no longer continue receiving such new versions and updates, our revenue could decline significantly, and/or our costs could increase significantly, thereby negatively impacting our operating results.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Unexpected delays or announcement of delays by Microsoft related to product releases of Windows Embedded and/or Windows Mobile operating systems could adversely affect our revenue and operating results.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Unexpected delays or announcement of delays in Microsoft s delivery schedule for new versions of its Windows Embedded and/or Windows Mobile operating systems could cause us to delay our product introductions or impede our ability to sell our products and services and/or to complete customer projects on a timely basis.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S6	Such delays, or announcements of delays, by Microsoft could also cause our customers to delay or cancel their project development activities or product introductions, which could negatively impact our revenue and operating results.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S7	If Microsoft adds features to its Windows operating systems or develops products that directly compete with products and services we provide, our revenue and operating results could be negatively impacted.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S8	As the developer of Windows, Windows Embedded Compact, Windows Embedded Standard, Windows Server, Windows Embedded Standard, Windows Embedded Compact, and Windows Mobile operating systems, Microsoft could add features which eliminate or reduce our customers need for our software and services, or Microsoft could develop standalone products and services that compete with the products and services we provide to our customers.
1054721_12_ITEM1A_P6_S9	The ability of our customers, or potential customers, to obtain products and services directly from Microsoft that compete with our products and services could negatively impact our revenue and operating results.
