1054721_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	This decrease was due to a $3.8 million decline in North America service revenue driven primarily by a $1.9 million decrease associated with the MyFord Touch Program and net decreases from other North America customers.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P34_S2	We also experienced a $1.8 million decline in Japan and a $1.0 million decline in EMEA due to decreases in activity from large customers.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ) became our largest engineering services customer during the first quarter of 2012, replacing Ford Motor Company ( Ford ), as Microsoft replaced Ford as the invoiced customer on the MyFord Touch program.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	We continue to work on the MyFord Touch, a project we began with Ford during the second quarter of 2008; however, we now conduct these services through an agreement with Microsoft.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	During the initial project with Ford, we provided hardware design and implementation, platform level software development, application level software development, quality assurance services and systems integration services.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	The project has transitioned since the initial project such that we are now primarily focused on developing and integrating new user applications for the MyFord Touch, enhancing existing applications and customizing the MyFord Touch platform for additional vehicle models.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	The MyFord Touch program contributed $4.5 million in service revenue in 2013 compared to $6.4 million in 2012 representing a decline of $1.9 million or 30%.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	The decrease is attributable to a reduction in the number of engineers working on the MyFord Touch project as the amount of work on the increasingly mature platform has declined.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	Gross profit and gross margin Cost of software revenue consists primarily of the cost of third-party software products payable to third-party vendors and support costs associated with our proprietary software products.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	Cost of service revenue consists primarily of salaries and benefits, contractor costs and re-billable expenses, related facilities and depreciation costs, and amortization of certain intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	Gross profit on the sale of third-party software products is also positively affected by rebate credits we receive from Microsoft for the sale of Windows Embedded operating systems earned through the achievement of defined objectives.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S3	Prior to the third quarter of 2013, the earned rebate amount was treated as a reduction in software cost of sales in the quarter earned.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S4	Beginning in the third quarter of 2013, as a result of program modifications, we began treating a portion of the rebate as marketing development funds which are accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S5	Under this rebate program, we earned $744,000 of rebate credits in 2013 and $888,000 in 2012, which were treated as a reduction in cost of sales.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P37_S6	Additionally, during 2013 we earned $409,000 in rebate credits which will be accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified expenditures are made.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	The following table outlines software, services and total gross profit (dollars in thousands):
1054721_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	Software gross profit and gross margin Software gross profit decreased by $1.8 million, or 12%, in 2013, compared to 2012, while software gross margin decreased by one percentage point.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	The decreases in gross profit and gross margin were primarily the result of the decline in high-margin proprietary software revenue.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	Third-party software gross margin was 16% in both 2013 and 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	Proprietary software gross margin was 66% in 2013, compared to 78% in 2012 driven by the revenue decline compared to a relatively fixed cost of sales base.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	Service gross profit and gross margin Service gross profit decreased $2.3 million, or 52%, in 2013 compared to 2012 driven by a $6.9 million decline in service revenue without a commensurate decline in service cost of sales.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	Service gross margin was 11% in 2013, a six percentage point decrease from 17% in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S4	The margin decline was driven by a 5% increase in our cost per billable hour due to lower utilization and fixed cost increases and a decline in our realized rate per hour of 2%.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P40_S5	During the fourth quarter of 2013, we made adjustments to reduce service related expenses to better align our costs with our future service revenue expectations which included the closure of our Beijing China delivery center.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	Operating expenses Selling, general and administrative Selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of salaries and related benefits, commissions and bonuses for our sales, marketing and administrative personnel and related facilities and depreciation costs, as well as professional services fees (e.g., consulting, legal and audit).
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S1	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $1.1 million, or 8%, to $15.4 million in 2013, from $14.3 million in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S2	The increase was driven by severance and related costs associated with the departure of our former Chief Executive Officer in September 2013 and the departure of our former Senior Vice President of Worldwide Sales and Marketing in December 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S3	Additionally, the increase was driven by higher sales travel and entertainment costs and legal expenses.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S4	Selling, general and administrative expenses represented 17% of our total revenue in 2013 compared to 14% of revenue in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S5	Research and development Research and development expenses consist primarily of salaries and benefits for software development and quality assurance personnel, contractor and consultant costs and related facilities and depreciation costs.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S6	Research and development expenses decreased $843,000, or 23%, to $2.8 million in 2013, from $3.6 million in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S7	The decline was driven by lower wage and other expenses associated primarily with two separate cost reduction efforts one in the third quarter of 2012 and another in the fourth quarter of 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P41_S8	Research and development expenses represented 3% of total revenue in 2013 and 4% in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	Other income, net Other income consists of interest income on our cash and investments, gains and losses we may recognize on our investments, gains or losses on foreign exchange transactions and other items.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	Other income was $40,000 in 2013 compared to $103,000 in 2012, representing a decline of $63,000 which was driven by a one-time reduction to earn-out consideration in 2012 related to the September 2011 acquisition of MPC Data, Ltd.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	Income taxes Income tax expense was $2.2 million in 2013, compared to $366,000 in the year-ago period, a change of $1.8 million.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	In the third quarter of 2013, we determined that it was not more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to utilize our US deferred tax assets.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	As a result, we increased our deferred tax asset valuation allowance by $2.2 million.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P43_S2	Deferred tax assets relative to our foreign jurisdictions were not affected.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	The factors we considered in recording a full valuation allowance on our US deferred tax assets included, among other things, our recent history of losses.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	Restructuring During the fourth quarter of 2013, we effected a restructuring that included a workforce reduction and the closure of our offices in Beijing, China and Munich, Germany.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S2	The workforce reduction impacted approximately 20% of our worldwide workforce.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S3	The restructuring was intended to better align our organizational structure with our strategic focus.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S4	The staff reductions and office closures were substantially completed by the end of the fourth quarter of 2013 with some activities, including legal entity closures, continuing into 2014.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S5	The results of this restructuring and associated asset impairment were recorded within loss from operations on our Consolidated Statement of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss) .
1054721_14_ITEM7_P44_S6	See Note 12: Restructuring in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2013, we had $21.1 million of cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash, compared to $20.6 million at December 31, 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	Of these amounts, $13.5 million and $9.9 million were classified as cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012, respectively, Restricted cash is classified as long term and was $250,000 at December 31, 2013 and $875,000 at December 31, 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	This cash is restricted under the terms of our headquarters operating lease which will continue to secure that obligation through its expiration in 2020.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S3	Our working capital was $19.8 million at December 31, 2013, compared to $20.6 million at December 31, 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S4	Net cash provided by operating activities was $619,000 in 2013, driven by positive net working capital changes of $2.1 million and non-cash expenses of $3.8 million, which were offset substantially by our net loss of $5.3 million.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S5	Net cash provided by operating activities was $2.5 million in 2012 driven by net income of $916,000 and non-cash expenses of $2.2 million, offset in part by net negative working capital changes.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S6	Investing activities provided cash of $3.0 million in 2013, due primarily to net proceeds of short-term investments of $2.5 million and a $625,000 reduction in restricted cash under the terms of our corporate headquarters lease amendment executed in August 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S7	Net cash used by investing activities was $1.2 million in 2012 driven by $391,000 in capital expenditures and payment of contingent acquisition consideration related to MPC of $631,000.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P45_S8	Financing activities generated $51,000 in 2013 and $205,000 in 2012, as a result of the exercise of employee stock options.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	We believe that our existing cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and long-term investments will be sufficient to meet our needs for working capital and capital expenditures for at least the next 12 months.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	Cash Commitments We have the following future or potential cash commitments:
1054721_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	In conjunction with our activities under our ODAs with Microsoft, we enter OVRP commitments with Microsoft.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	Under these OVRPs, we are provided with volume pricing on a customer-by-customer basis assuming certain minimum unit volumes are met.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	The OVRP terms are 12 months.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	committed per-unit volume rate and the actual per-unit rate we achieved based upon actual units purchased.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	The OVRP arrangements do not equate to a minimum purchase commitment but rather, the arrangements are a volume pricing arrangement based upon actual volume purchased.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P48_S2	In substantially all instances, we have reciprocal agreements with our customers such that we will receive per-unit price adjustments, similar to the amounts we would subsequently owe to Microsoft if such OVRP volumes are not met.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P48_S3	However, in the event a customer is unwilling or unable to pay us, we would be negatively impacted.
1054721_14_ITEM7_P48_S4	Based upon the credit-worthiness of our customers, our historical OVRP experience with our customers and OVRP arrangements in general, we do not believe we will incur any material liability in the current or future periods.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of BSQUARE Corporation (the Corporation ) as of December 31, 2013 and 2012 and the related consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive income (loss), shareholders equity and cash flows for the years then ended.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Corporation s management.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S5	The Corporation is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S6	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Corporation s internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P0_S7	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P1_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall consolidated financial statement presentation.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P1_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P1_S2	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of BSQUARE Corporation as of December 31, 2013 and 2012, and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P6_S0	Description of Business and Accounting Policies Description of Business BSQUARE Corporation ( BSQUARE ) was incorporated in Washington State in July 1994.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P7_S0	We provide software solutions and related engineering services to companies that develop smart, connected systems.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S0	A smart, connected system is a dedicated purpose computing device that typically has a display, runs an operating system (e.g., Microsoft Windows CE) and is usually connected to a network or data cloud via a wired or wireless connection.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S1	Examples of smart, connected systems include set-top boxes, home gateways, point-of-sale terminals, kiosks, voting machines, gaming platforms, tablets, handheld data collection devices, personal media players, smart phones, vending machines and in-vehicle telematics and entertainment devices.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S2	We focus on smart, connected systems that utilize Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems as well as devices running other popular operating systems such as Android, Linux, and QNX.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S3	We have been providing software solutions for smart, connected systems since our inception.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S4	Our customers include world class original equipment manufacturers ( OEMs ), original design manufacturers ( ODMs ) and corporate enterprises ( Enterprises ), as well as silicon vendors ( SVs ) and peripheral vendors which purchase our software solutions for purposes of facilitating processor and peripheral sales.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S5	In the case of Enterprises, our customers include those which develop, market and distribute smart, connected systems on their own behalf as well as those that purchase systems from OEMs or ODMs and require additional software, integration and/or testing.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P8_S6	The software solutions we provide are utilized and deployed throughout various phases of our customers device life cycle, including design, development, customization, quality assurance and deployment.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P9_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of BSQUARE Corporation and our wholly owned subsidiaries.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P9_S1	All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P10_S0	Use of Estimates Preparing financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P10_S1	Examples include provisions for bad debts and income taxes, estimates of progress on professional engineering service arrangements, bonus accruals, fair value of intangible assets and property and equipment, fair values of stock-based awards and the fair values of acquired assets and liabilities, among other estimates.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P10_S2	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S0	Basic income or loss per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period, and excludes any dilutive effects of common stock equivalent shares, such as options, restricted stock awards, restricted stock units and warrants.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S1	Restricted stock awards ( RSAs ) are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income or loss per share when underlying restrictions expire and the awards are no longer forfeitable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S2	Restricted stock units ( RSUs ) are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income or loss per share only when vested.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S3	Diluted income per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding and common stock equivalent shares outstanding during the period using the treasury stock method.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S4	Common stock equivalent shares are excluded from the computation if their effect is anti-dilutive.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P11_S5	Unvested but outstanding RSUs and RSAs (which are forfeitable) are included in the diluted income per share calculation.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	In a period where we are in a net loss position, the diluted loss per share is computed using the basic share count.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	The following table presents a reconciliation of the number of shares used in the calculation of basic and diluted income (loss) per share (in thousands): Common stock equivalent shares of 990,831 and 1,034,183 were excluded from the computations of basic and diluted income per share for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012, respectively, because their effect was anti-dilutive.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	Unvested but outstanding RSUs and RSAs which are forfeitable are included in the diluted income per share calculation.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	In a period where we are in a net loss position, the diluted loss per share is computed using the basic share count.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	We invest our excess cash primarily in highly liquid debt instruments of U.S. government agencies and municipalities, debt instruments issued by foreign government, corporate commercial paper, money market funds, and corporate debt securities.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S1	We classify all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of three months or less from date of purchase as cash equivalents and all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of greater than three months as short-term investments.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S2	Short-term investments consist entirely of marketable securities which are all classified as available-for-sale securities and are recorded at their estimated fair value.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S3	We determine the appropriate classification of our investments at the time of purchase and reevaluate such designation at each balance sheet date.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S4	We may or may not hold securities with stated maturities greater than 12 months until maturity.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S5	As we view these securities as available to support current operations, we classify securities with maturities beyond 12 months as short-term investments.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P16_S6	We carry these securities at fair value, and report the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, as a component of stockholders equity, except for unrealized losses determined to be other than temporary which are recorded in other expense.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	Restricted Cash Our restricted cash represents funds held at a financial institution as security for an outstanding letter of credit expiring in 2020 related to our corporate headquarters lease obligation.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	Financial Instruments and Concentrations of Risk Financial instruments that potentially subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash equivalents, short-term investments, and accounts receivable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts We record accounts receivable at the invoiced amount net of an estimated allowance for doubtful accounts to reserve for potentially uncollectible receivables.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P18_S2	We review customers which are past due to identify specific customers with known disputes or collectability issues.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P18_S3	In determining the amount of the allowance, we make judgments about the creditworthiness of significant customers based on ongoing credit evaluations.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	Equipment, Furniture and Leasehold Improvements We account for equipment, furniture and leasehold improvements at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	We compute depreciation of equipment and furniture using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets, generally three years.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	straight-line method over the shorter of the lease term or estimated useful lives, ranging from two to ten years.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P20_S1	Maintenance and repairs costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	When assets are retired or otherwise disposed of, gains or losses are included in the statement of operations.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	When facts and circumstances indicate that the value of long-lived assets may be impaired, an evaluation of recoverability is performed by comparing the carrying value of the asset to projected undiscounted future cash flows.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	Upon indication that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable, we recognize an impairment loss as a charge against current operations based on the difference between the carrying value of the asset and its fair value.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	Intangible Assets Intangible assets were recorded as a result of business acquisitions and are stated at estimated fair value at the time of acquisition less accumulated amortization.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	We amortize our acquired intangible assets using the straight-line method using lives ranging from one to ten years.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	We review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	We measure recoverability of these assets by comparing the carrying amounts to the future undiscounted cash flows the assets are expected to generate.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	If intangible assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment to be recognized equals the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair market value.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P26_S1	Goodwill We evaluate goodwill for impairment annually or more frequently when an event occurs or circumstances change that indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P26_S2	We test goodwill for impairment by performing a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying amount.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P26_S3	If it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is greater than the carrying amount, no further testing is performed.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	If it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying amount, we perform a quantitative two-step impairment test.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	The first step compares the fair value of the reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	If the carrying amount exceeds fair value, then the second step of the impairment test is performed to measure the amount of any impairment loss.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	We record all fees payable and accrued liabilities related to the sale of third-party software, such as Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, as third-party software fees payable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	Research and Development Research and development costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	Advertising Costs All costs of advertising, including cooperative marketing arrangements, are expensed as incurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P30_S2	Advertising expense was $501,000 in 2013 and $733,000 in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	The estimated fair value of stock based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of our common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P32_S2	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P33_S1	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	Incentive Compensation We make certain estimates, judgments and assumptions regarding the likelihood of our attainment, and the level thereof, of bonuses payable under our annual incentive compensation programs.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	We accrue bonuses and recognize the resulting expense when the bonus is judged to be reasonably likely to be earned as of year-end and is estimable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	The amount accrued, and expense recognized, is the estimated portion of the bonus earned on a year-to-date basis less any amounts previously accrued.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S3	These estimates, judgments and assumptions are made quarterly based on available information and take into consideration our year-to-date actual results and expected results for the remainder of the year.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S4	Because our attainment estimate factors estimated future results, significant judgment is required.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P34_S5	If actual results differ materially from our estimates, the amount of bonus expense recorded in a particular quarter could be significantly over or under estimated.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	Comprehensive Income (Loss) Comprehensive income (loss) refers to net income (loss) and other revenue, expenses, gains and losses that, under generally accepted accounting principles, are recorded as an element of shareholders equity but are excluded from the calculation of net income (loss).
1054721_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	Income Taxes We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and certain foreign jurisdictions.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P36_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	We compute income taxes using the asset and liability method, under which deferred income taxes are provided for on the temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and the tax basis of our assets and liabilities.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	Our deferred tax amounts are measured using currently enacted tax rates that are expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P37_S2	A valuation allowance is established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	We recognize tax benefits from an uncertain position only if it is more likely than not that the position is sustainable, based on its technical merits.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	The tax benefit of a qualifying position is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P38_S2	Interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions are classified in the financial statements as income tax expense.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	The functional currency of foreign subsidiaries is their local currency.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P39_S1	Accordingly, assets and liabilities are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P39_S2	Resulting translation adjustments are included in Other Comprehensive Income (Loss) and Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss , a separate component of shareholders equity.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	The net gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are recorded in the period incurred and were not significant for any of the periods presented.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	We recognize revenue from software and engineering service sales when the following four revenue recognition criteria are met: persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists; delivery has occurred or services have been rendered; the selling price is fixed or determinable; and collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	Contracts and customer purchase orders are generally used to determine the existence of an arrangement.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	and time records are generally used to verify delivery.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	We assess whether the selling price is fixed or determinable based on the contract and/or customer purchase order and payment terms associated with the transaction and whether the sales price is subject to refund or adjustment.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P43_S1	We assess collectability based primarily on the creditworthiness of the customer as determined by credit checks and analysis, as well as the customer s payment history.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P43_S2	Periodically, we will begin work on engineering service engagements prior to having a signed contract and, in some cases, the contract is signed in a quarter after which service delivery costs are incurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P43_S3	We do not defer costs associated with such engagements before we have received a signed contract.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P43_S4	We recognize software revenue upon shipment provided that no significant obligations remain on our part, substantive acceptance conditions, if any, have been met and the other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	Service revenue from time and materials contracts, and training service agreements, is recognized as services are performed.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P44_S1	Fixed-price service agreements, and certain time and materials service agreements with capped fee structures, are accounted for using the percentage-of-completion method assuming reasonable estimates of completion can be made.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	We use the percentage-of-completion method of accounting because we believe it is the most accurate method to recognize revenue based on the nature and scope of these engineering service contracts; we believe it is a better measure of periodic income results than other methods and it better matches revenue recognized with the costs incurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	Percentage of completion is measured based primarily on input measures such as hours incurred to date compared to total estimated hours to complete, with consideration given to output measures, such as contract milestones, when applicable.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P45_S2	Significant judgment is required when estimating total hours and progress to completion on these arrangements which determines the amount of revenue we recognize as well as whether a loss is recognized if one is expected to be incurred for the remainder of the project.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	Revisions to hour and cost estimates are incorporated in the period in which the facts that give rise to the revision become known.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	We also enter into arrangements in which a customer purchases a combination of software licenses, engineering services and post-contract customer support and/or maintenance ( PCS ).
1054721_14_ITEM8_P47_S1	As a result, judgment is sometimes required to determine the appropriate accounting, including how the price should be allocated among the deliverable elements if there are multiple elements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	PCS may include rights to upgrades, when and if available, telephone support, updates and enhancements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	When vendor specific objective evidence ( VSOE ) of fair value exists for all elements in a multiple element arrangement, revenue is allocated to each element based on the relative fair value of each of the elements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P49_S1	VSOE of fair value is established by the price charged when the same element is sold separately.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P49_S2	Accordingly, the judgments involved in assessing the fair values of various elements of an agreement can impact the recognition of revenue in each period.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P49_S3	Changes in the allocation of the sales price between deliverables might impact the timing of revenue recognition, but would not change the total revenue recognized on the contract.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	When elements such as software and engineering services are contained in a single arrangement, or in related arrangements with the same customer, we allocate revenue to each element based on its relative fair value, provided that such element meets the criteria for treatment as a separate unit of accounting.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	In the absence of fair value for a delivered element, revenue is first allocated to the fair value of the undelivered elements and then allocated to the residual delivered elements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	In the absence of fair value for an undelivered element, the arrangement is accounted for as a single unit of accounting, resulting in a delay of revenue recognition for the delivered elements until the undelivered elements are fulfilled.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	When engineering services and royalties are contained in a single arrangement, we recognize revenue from engineering services as earned in accordance with the criteria above even though the effective rate per hour may be lower than typical because the customer is contractually obligated to pay royalties on their device shipments.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P51_S1	We recognize royalty revenue, classified as software revenue, when the royalty report from the customer is received or when such royalties are contractually guaranteed and the other revenue recognition criteria are met, particularly the criteria that collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists to bring conformity in the presentation of unrecognized tax benefits when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward exists.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	ASU 2013-11 became effective for us on January 1, 2014.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	We do not believe the adoption of this guidance will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements or notes to the consolidated financial statements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	In February 2013, the FASB issued ASU No. 2013-02, Reporting of Amounts Reclassified Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	Under ASU 2013-02, an entity is required to provide information about the amounts reclassified out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income ( AOCI ) by component.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P54_S2	In addition, an entity is required to present, either on the face of the financial statements or in the notes, significant amounts reclassified out of AOCI by the respective line items of net income, but only if the amount reclassified is required to be reclassified in its entirety in the same reporting period.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P54_S3	For amounts that are not required to be reclassified in their entirety to net income, an entity is required to cross-reference to other disclosures that provide additional details about those amounts.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	ASU 2013-02 does not change the current requirements for reporting net income or other comprehensive income in the financial statements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P55_S1	Our adoption of ASU 2013-02 effective January 1, 2013 did not have any effect on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	Cash and Investments Cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments, and restricted cash consist of the following (in thousands):
1054721_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	Gross unrealized gains and losses on our cash equivalents and short-term investments were not material as of December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P57_S1	Our restricted cash balance at December 31, 2013 and 2012 relates to a letter of credit which secures our corporate headquarters lease.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	Fair Value Measurements We measure our cash equivalents, marketable securities and restricted cash at fair value.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P58_S1	Fair value is an exit price, representing the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P58_S2	As such, fair value is a market-based measurement that should be determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or a liability.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P58_S3	A three-tier fair value hierarchy is established as a basis for considering such assumptions and for inputs used in the valuation methodologies in measuring fair value:
1054721_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	Level 1: Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	Level 2: Directly or indirectly observable market-based inputs or unobservable inputs used in models or other valuation methodologies.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	Level 3: Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P61_S1	The inputs require significant management judgment or estimation.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	We classify our cash equivalents, marketable securities and restricted cash within Level 1 or Level 2.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P62_S1	This is because we value these items using quoted market prices or alternative pricing sources and models utilizing market observable inputs that are actively quoted and can be validated through external sources, including third-party pricing services, brokers and market transactions.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P62_S2	We review the pricing techniques and methodologies of the independent pricing service for Level 2 investments and believe that the policies adequately consider market activity, either based on specific transactions for the security valued or based on modeling of securities with similar credit quality, duration, yield and structure that were recently traded.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	Assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized below (in thousands):
1054721_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	Equipment, Furniture and Leasehold Improvements Equipment, furniture, and leasehold improvements consist of the following (in thousands): Depreciation and amortization expense of equipment, furniture and leasehold improvements was $495,000 in 2013 and $672,000 in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P64_S1	In 2013, we wrote off approximately $1.4 million of fully depreciated assets.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P65_S1	The excess of the acquisition consideration over the fair value of net assets acquired was recorded as goodwill.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	Our net deferred tax assets are recorded as follows (in thousands):
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S0	As of December 31, 2013, our deferred tax assets were primarily the result of U.S. NOL and tax credit carryforwards.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S1	A valuation allowance of $27.7 million and $24.1 million was recorded against our gross deferred tax asset balance as of December 31, 2013, and December 31, 2012, respectively.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2013, we recorded an increase in valuation allowance of $3.6 million on the basis of management s reassessment of the amount of its deferred tax assets that are more likely than not to be realized.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S3	As of each reporting date, our management considers new evidence, both positive and negative, that could impact management s view with regard to future realization of deferred tax assets.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S4	In the third quarter of 2013, we determined that is was not more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to utilize the portion of our net US deferred tax assets, which had been previously recognized, and we increased our valuation allowance in the U.S. by $2.2 million.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P73_S5	Deferred tax assets relative to our foreign tax jurisdictions were not affected.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	The provision for income taxes differs from the amount of expected income tax expense (benefit) determined by applying the applicable U.S. statutory federal income tax rate to pre-tax income (loss), as a result of the following: At December 31, 2013, we had approximately $55.6 million of federal and $9.3 million of state net operating loss carryforwards, which have begun to expire, including $3.3 million of state losses in 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P74_S1	Of the federal net operating loss carryforwards, an aggregate of $42.5 million will expire in 2022 and 2023.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P74_S2	We also have $2.7 million of tax credit carryforwards, which begin to expire in 2018.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P74_S3	Utilization of these carryforwards may be subject to an annual limitation due to Section 382 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code which restricts the ability of a corporation that undergoes an ownership change to use its carryforwards.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	Under the applicable tax rules, an ownership change occurs if holders of more than five percent of an issuer s outstanding common stock, collectively, increase their ownership percentage by more than 50 percentage points over a rolling three-year period.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P75_S1	We performed analyses of possible ownership changes, which included consideration of a third party study completed in 2012, and do not believe that an ownership change of more than 50 percentage points has occurred.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P75_S2	While the study has not been updated in 2013, we do not believe there have been any further impacts on the results of that analysis in 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P75_S3	We have evaluated all the material income tax positions taken on our income tax filings to various tax authorities, and we determined that we did not have unrealized tax benefits related to uncertain tax positions recorded at December 31, 2013 or 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P75_S4	Because of net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards, substantially all of our tax years remain open and subject to examination.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	Our commitments include obligations outstanding under operating leases, which expire through 2020.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P76_S1	We have lease commitments for office space in Bellevue, Washington; San Diego, California; Boston, Massachusetts; Taipei, Taiwan; Tokyo, Japan; and Trowbridge, UK.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P76_S2	We also lease office space on a month-to-month basis in Akron, Ohio.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P76_S3	In August 2013, we amended the lease agreement for our Bellevue, Washington headquarters and extended the term of the original lease that was scheduled to expire in August 2014 to May 2020.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P76_S4	Rent expense was $1.6 million in 2013 and $1.8 million in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P77_S0	As of December 31, 2013, we had $250,000 pledged as collateral for a bank letter of credit under the terms of our headquarters facility lease.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P77_S1	The pledged cash supporting the outstanding letter of credit is recorded as restricted cash.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S0	In conjunction with our activities under the OEM Distribution Agreements ( ODAs ) with Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ), we enter into OEM Volume Royalty Pricing ( OVRP ) commitments with Microsoft.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S1	Under these OVRPs, we are provided with volume pricing on a customer-by-customer basis assuming certain minimum unit volumes are met.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S2	The OVRP terms are 12 months.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S3	In the event we don t meet the committed minimum unit volumes, we are obligated to pay the difference between the committed per-unit volume rate and the actual per-unit rate we achieved based upon actual units purchased.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S4	The OVRP arrangements do not equate to a minimum purchase commitment but rather, the arrangements are a volume pricing arrangement based upon actual volume purchased.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S5	In substantially all instances, we have reciprocal agreements with our customers such that we will receive per-unit price adjustments, similar to the amounts we would subsequently owe to Microsoft if such OVRP volumes are not met.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S6	However, in the event a customer is unwilling or unable to pay us, we would be negatively impacted.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P78_S7	Based upon the credit-worthiness of our customers, our historical OVRP experience with our customers and OVRP arrangements in general, we do not believe we will incur any material liability in the current or future periods relating to existing agreements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P79_S0	Shareholders Equity Equity Compensation Plans We have a stock plan (the Stock Plan ) and an inducement stock plan for newly hired employees (the Inducement Plan ) (collectively the Plans ).
1054721_14_ITEM8_P79_S1	Under the Plans, stock options may be granted with a fixed exercise price that is equivalent to fair market value on the date of grant.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P79_S2	These options have a term of up to 10 years and vest over a predetermined period, generally four years.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P79_S3	Incentive stock options granted under the Stock Plan may only be granted to our employees.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P79_S4	The Plans also allow for awards of non-qualified stock options, stock appreciation rights, RSAs and unrestricted stock awards, and RSUs.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P80_S0	The estimated fair value of stock-based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P81_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P82_S0	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P82_S1	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P82_S2	The BSM model requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P82_S3	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P84_S0	The following table summarizes stock option activity under the Plans for 2013 and 2012:

1054721_14_ITEM8_P85_S1	This cost will be amortized on the straight-line method over a weighted-average period of approximately 1.3 years.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P86_S0	The aggregate intrinsic value represents the difference between the exercise price of the underlying options and the quoted price of our common stock for the number of options that were in-the-money at year end.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P90_S0	We have a Profit Sharing and Deferred Compensation Plan ( Profit Sharing Plan ) under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P90_S1	Substantially all full-time employees are eligible to participate in the Profit Sharing Plan.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P90_S2	We typically elect to match the participants contributions to the Profit Sharing Plan up to a certain amount subject to vesting.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P90_S3	Participants will receive their share of the value of their investments, and any applicable vested match, upon retirement or termination.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S0	We have ODAs with Microsoft which enable us to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems to our customers in the United States, Canada, the Caribbean (excluding Cuba), Mexico, the European Union and the European Free Trade Association, which expire on June 30, 2014.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S1	We also have ODAs with Microsoft which allow us to sell Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems in the Americas, Japan, Taiwan, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S2	Our current distribution agreements related to Windows Mobile expire on June 30, 2014.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S3	Our rights to distribute Windows Mobile operating systems in Korea expired on October 31, 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S4	We sold $4.5 million of Windows Mobile operating systems in Korea in 2012.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S5	Software sales under these agreements constitute a significant portion of our software revenue and total revenue.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S6	These agreements are typically renewed annually or semi-annually; however, there is no automatic renewal provision in any of these agreements.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P92_S7	Further, these agreements can be terminated unilaterally by Microsoft at any time.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S0	Microsoft currently offers a rebate program to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems pursuant to which we earn money for achieving certain predefined objectives.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S1	Prior to the third quarter of 2013, the earned rebate amount was treated as a reduction in software cost of sales in the quarter earned.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S2	Beginning in the third quarter of 2013, as a result of program modifications, we began treating a portion of the rebate as marketing development funds which are accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S3	Under this rebate program, we earned $774,000 in 2013 and $888,000 in 2012, which was treated as a reduction in cost of sales.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S4	Additionally, in 2013, we earned $409,000 which will be accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S5	During the fourth quarter of 2013, we effected a restructuring that included a workforce reduction and the closure of our offices in Beijing, China and Munich, Germany.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S6	The workforce reduction impacted approximately 20% of our worldwide workforce.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P93_S7	The restructuring was intended to better align our organizational structure with our strategic focus.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P94_S0	The staff reductions and office closures were substantially completed by the end of the fourth quarter of 2013 with some activities, including legal entity closures, continuing into 2014.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P97_S0	Information about Geographic Areas Our chief operating decision-makers (i.e., chief executive officer, and certain of his direct reports) review financial information presented on a consolidated basis, accompanied by disaggregated information about revenues by geographic region for purposes of allocating resources and evaluating financial performance.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P97_S1	There are no segment managers who are held accountable by our chief operating decision-makers, or anyone else, for operations, operating results, and planning for levels or components below the consolidated unit level.
1054721_14_ITEM8_P97_S2	Accordingly, we consider ourselves to be in a single reporting segment and operating unit structure.

1054721_14_ITEM8_P99_S0	Following is a summary of unaudited quarterly financial information for 2013 and 2012:
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S0	disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that the information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In connection with the preparation of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, our management carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our CEO and CFO, as of December 31, 2013, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as such term is defined under Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Based upon this evaluation, our CEO and CFO concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S4	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of our financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S5	Internal control over financial reporting is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) promulgated under the Exchange Act and includes those policies and procedures that: (a) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our assets; (b) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that our receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of our management and directors; and (c) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of our assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S6	All internal controls, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P0_S7	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P1_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) .
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Based on its assessment, our management concluded that, as of December 31, 2013, our internal control over financial reporting was effective.
1054721_14_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of 2013 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.

1054721_15_ITEM1_P0_S0	CAUTIONARY NOTE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS This Annual Report on Form 10-K contains "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the safe-harbor provisions of the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P1_S0	Forward-looking statements can often be identified by words such as: "expect," "believe," "estimate," "plan," "strategy," "future," "potential," "continue," "may," "should," "will," and similar references to future periods.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P1_S1	Examples include, among others, statements about: expected operating results, such as revenue growth and earnings; anticipated levels of capital expenditures; future market conditions; our belief that we have sufficient liquidity to fund our business operations for at least the next 12 months; expectations of the effect on our financial condition of claims, litigation, contingent liabilities and supplier audits; and strategies for customer retention, growth, product and service development, and market position.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S0	Forward-looking statements are neither historical facts nor assurances about future performance.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S1	Instead they are only predictions, based on current beliefs, expectations and assumptions about the future of our business and other future conditions.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S2	Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and changes in circumstances that are difficult to predict and many of which are outside of our control.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S3	Actual events and results may differ materially.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S4	Therefore, you should not rely on any of these forward-looking statements.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S5	Any forward-looking statement made by us in this report is based only on information available to us on the date of this report.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S6	Except as may be required by law, we undertake no obligation to publicly update any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future developments or otherwise.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S7	Our forward-looking statements can be affected by inaccurate assumptions we might make or by known or unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S8	We discuss many of these risks, uncertainties and other factors in this Annual Report on Form 10-K in greater detail under the Item 1A Risk Factors.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S9	We caution readers that our business and financial performance are subject to substantial risks and uncertainties.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P2_S10	BUSINESS Overview As used in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, we, us , our , the Company and Bsquare refer to BSQUARE Corporation.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P3_S0	We primarily resell software from Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ) and provide software solutions and related engineering services to companies that develop smart, connected systems.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S0	A smart, connected system is a dedicated purpose computing device that typically has a display, runs an operating system (e.g., Microsoft Windows CE or Google Android TM platform) and is usually connected to a network or data cloud via a wired or wireless connection.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S1	Examples of smart, connected systems include set-top boxes, home gateways, point-of-sale terminals, kiosks, voting machines, gaming platforms, tablets, handheld data collection devices, personal media players, smart phones, smart vending machines and in-vehicle telematics and entertainment devices.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S2	We focus on smart, connected systems that utilize various Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems as well as devices running other popular operating systems such as Android, Linux, and QNX.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S3	We have been providing software solutions for smart, connected systems since our inception.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our customers include world class original equipment manufacturers ( OEMs ), original design manufacturers ( ODMs ) and corporate enterprises ( Enterprises ), as well as silicon vendors ( SVs ) and peripheral vendors which purchase our software solutions for purposes of facilitating processor and peripheral sales.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S5	In the case of Enterprises, our customers include those that develop, market and distribute smart, connected systems on their own behalf as well as those that purchase systems from OEMs or ODMs and require additional software, integration and/or testing.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S6	The software solutions we provide are utilized and deployed throughout various phases of our customers device life cycle, including design, development, customization, quality assurance and deployment.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S7	Increasingly, we intend to focus on developing and offering our own products such as DataV TM to address the emerging Internet of Things ( IoT ) market, which is the interconnection of uniquely identifiable embedded computing devices within the existing internet infrastructure.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P4_S8	Similarly, we intend to focus on increasing the amount of our own products and know-how, including in our MobileV TM product, a complete hardware and software reference solution for OEMs building durable and rugged handhelds and industrial tablets.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P5_S0	We were incorporated in the State of Washington in July 1994.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P5_S1	Our principal office is located at 110 110th Avenue NE, Suite 300, Bellevue, Washington 98004, and our telephone number is (425) 519-5900.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P6_S0	The increasing opportunity for connectivity and exchange of data coupled with the rise of cloud storage and cloud computing infrastructure is driving new applications for smart, connected systems of all kinds.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P7_S0	The smart, connected systems industry is characterized by a wide variety of software and hardware configurations and end-user applications, often designed to address a specific vertical market.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P7_S1	To accommodate these diverse characteristics in a cost-effective manner, OEMs, ODMs and Enterprises require operating systems and software that can support a diverse set of hardware requirements and connect to a wide variety of networks, systems, peripherals, content and applications.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P7_S2	The smart, connected systems marketplace is being influenced by the following factors:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P8_S0	Expectations for device functionality continue to grow.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P9_S0	Security is an increasingly important concern as devices are now often able to access networks and store sensitive information locally such as email, spreadsheets and other documents.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P10_S0	Increase in device complexity is being driven by rising user expectations of functionality, complex device interactions with wireless networks and updated versions of embedded operating systems and silicon processors, all of which are driving OEMs, ODMs and Enterprises to continually refresh and update their device designs.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P11_S0	Our customers include world class OEMs and ODMs, Enterprises, SVs and peripheral vendors which are developing smart connected systems or assisting others in doing so.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P11_S1	Representative customer engagements in 2014 included the following:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P12_S0	We continued support of the second generation of MyFord Touch, a product of Ford Motor Company ( Ford ).
1054721_15_ITEM1_P13_S0	We have been a supplier to Outerwall (formerly Coinstar) since 2005 for their Windows Embedded Operating Systems that are deployed on their Coin Kiosks.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P13_S1	During the last several years we have provided Outerwall with engineering services for their New Venture Kiosks in addition to the Coin Kiosk.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P13_S2	In 2013 and 2014, we provided licensing consultation and engineering services for the Redbox division of Outerwall.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P14_S0	The Coca-Cola Company ( Coca-Cola ) continues to engage us in the development and support of Freestyle , its next generation drink dispensing machine.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P15_S0	We initiated work with Google to assist in the development of their advanced technology Project Tango.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P15_S1	We have expanded our work with Google to include additional projects.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P16_S0	The software we deliver to our customers as part of our smart connected software solutions takes three forms.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P16_S1	The first is our own proprietary software products, the second is best-of-class third-party software products and the last is custom software delivered through our engineering services teams.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P16_S2	The majority of the software we sell is from Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P16_S3	Due to the complexity of embedded software, the integration of our own proprietary software, third-party software products and customer software on customers devices often requires us to provide additional engineering services addressing systems integration, customization and/or optimization as well as quality assurance testing.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P16_S4	Our goal is to increase the breadth and depth of our software product and engineering service offerings to our customers to enhance our position as an overall smart connected software solutions provider.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P17_S0	Software revenue for the last two fiscal years was as follows (in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM1_P18_S0	We have distribution agreements with multiple third-party software vendors.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P18_S1	Our ability to resell these third-party software products, whether stand-alone or in conjunction with our own proprietary software and engineering service offerings, provides our customers with a significant solution source for their project needs.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P18_S2	Our primary third-party software offerings include the following:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P19_S0	For 16 years, we have been a Microsoft Corporation authorized Value-Added Provider ( VAP ) of Windows Embedded operating systems and toolkits for the complete line of Windows Embedded Products, including major product families such as Windows Embedded Compact, Windows Embedded Standard and Windows Embedded Server.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P19_S1	We are authorized to sell Windows Embedded operating systems in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Peru, Puerto Rico, the Caribbean (excluding Cuba), the European Union, the European Free Trade Association, Turkey and Africa.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P19_S2	Of our total revenue in 2014, 64% was generated through the sale of Windows Embedded operating systems, compared to 58% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P20_S0	We have been a Microsoft authorized VAP of Windows Mobile operating systems since November 2009.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P20_S1	Along with Windows Mobile operating systems, we also sell Microsoft s Office Mobile product.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P20_S2	We are currently authorized to sell Windows Mobile operating systems and related products in North America, South America, and Central America (excluding Cuba) (the Americas ), Japan, Taiwan, and the region comprised of Europe, the Middle East, and Africa ( EMEA ).
1054721_15_ITEM1_P20_S3	Of our total revenue in 2014, 9% was generated through the sale of Windows Mobile operating systems, compared to 11% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P21_S0	We are an authorized distributor for Adobe Flash technologies and Adobe Reader.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P22_S0	We sub-license and resell mobile handset design files from Aava Mobile Oy as a part of our MobileV product.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P23_S0	The sale of Microsoft operating systems has accounted for substantially all of our third-party software revenue historically, including 95% of third-party software revenue in 2014 and 90% of third-party software revenue in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P24_S0	Engineering Service Offerings We offer a variety of engineering services to our customers including:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P25_S0	Test Automation Engineering and Consulting Services.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P26_S0	Customers engage us for engineering services due to our extensive device software development and testing experience and because of our deep experience with embedded and mobile operating systems.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P27_S0	typically results in shorter development cycles and reduced time-to-market, lower overall costs to complete projects, and enhanced product robustness and features, which a customer may otherwise have been unable to achieve.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P28_S0	Service revenue for the last two fiscal years was as follows (in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM1_P29_S0	Service revenue related to Coca-Cola was $4.6 million, or 24% of 2014 service revenue and $3.2 million, or 17% or service revenue in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P29_S1	Service revenue related to the MyFord Touch program was $2.8 million, or 14% of service revenue, in 2014 and $4.5 million, or 24% of service revenue, in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P30_S0	Our primary proprietary software offerings being actively sold or developed include:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P31_S0	HTML5 Rendering Engine Our award-winning HTML5 Rendering Engine is based on the open-source WebKit platform which is maintained by a number of leading internet and device companies.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P31_S1	Using WebKit, device makers can create portable applications and user interfaces for their devices using the industry-standard HTML5 markup language.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P32_S0	DataV TM An actionable data solution for the IoT market.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P32_S1	DataV includes software products, applications and services that turn raw device data into useful, meaningful and actionable data.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P33_S0	MobileV TM A complete hardware and software reference solution based on Intel architecture, Microsoft Windows Embedded 8.1 and Google Android 4.4 operating systems.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P33_S1	MobileV provides a common platform for OEMs building multiple device form factors to include durable and rugged class handhelds and industrial tablets.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P33_S2	MobileV combines Windows Embedded 8.1 and Android 4.4 with cutting-edge Intel-based board designs from Aava Mobile, along with Bsquare s MobileV UX software, and significantly reduces engineering effort and time to market for next generation devices.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our strategy is to continue to enhance our position as a provider of software solutions and related engineering services for smart connected systems, ultimately becoming the go-to solutions provider for our customers and potential customers around the globe.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P34_S1	To advance this strategy, we intend to focus on the following:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P35_S0	Building our offerings and capabilities in the rapidly growing Internet of Things market.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P36_S0	Seeking additional software products, such as DataV and MobileV, in which to invest.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P37_S0	Relationship with Microsoft and Impact on our Smart Connected Solutions Business We have a long-standing relationship with Microsoft and this relationship is critical to the continuing success of our business.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P37_S1	Our credentials as a Microsoft partner include:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P38_S0	We have been engaged by Microsoft on various engineering service engagements.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P39_S0	We work closely with Microsoft executives, developers, product managers and sales personnel.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P39_S1	We leverage these relationships in a variety of ways, including:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P40_S0	We receive rebates from Microsoft based upon the achievement of predefined sales objectives.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P41_S0	See Item 1A, Risk Factors, for more information regarding our relationship with Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P42_S0	Customers Customers purchasing third-party software and our software solutions and engineering services include leading OEMs, ODMs, Enterprises, SVs and peripheral vendors seeking to leverage the software we provide them, be it our own proprietary software, third-party software or custom software developed via our engineering services, to develop high-quality, smart connected systems that meet the requirements of numerous end-markets.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P42_S1	Representative customers include Coca-Cola, Future Electronics, Elo Touch Solutions, Honeywell International, Inc., IGT, Microsoft, Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, Panasonic, Elektrobit, Bally and several industrial handset companies.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P43_S0	Sales and Marketing We market our software solutions and engineering services utilizing a direct sales model.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P43_S1	We have sales personnel throughout the United States and in Taiwan, the United Kingdom and Japan.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P44_S0	Historically, we have not made significant use of resellers, channel partners, representative agents or other indirect channels.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P44_S1	Key elements of our sales and marketing strategy include direct marketing, content marketing, trade shows, event marketing, public relations, analyst relations, social media properties, customer and strategic alliance partner co-marketing programs and a comprehensive website.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P44_S2	We rely significantly on lead referral and other marketing support programs from strategic partners.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P45_S0	Research and Development Our research and development personnel are responsible for the design, development and release of our proprietary software products.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P45_S1	Members of our research and development staff work closely with our sales and marketing departments, as well as with our customers and potential customers, to better understand market needs and requirements.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P45_S2	We perform our research and development primarily utilizing engineering staff located in the United States.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P45_S3	Research and development expense was $1.7 million and $2.8 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P45_S4	The decrease was driven largely by our cost reduction efforts in the fourth quarter of 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P46_S0	Competition The market for smart connected systems software and services is extremely competitive.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P46_S1	We face competition from the following:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P47_S0	Mobile and embedded test automation providers including Perfecto Mobile, mVerify, JAMO Solutions, SmartBear Software (AutomatedQA), TestPlant (eggPlant) and Keynote.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P48_S0	We will encounter increasing competition in the growing Internet of Things market from a number of additional software and service providers as we expand our focus on this market in 2015 and beyond.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S0	Some of our competitors focus on only one aspect of our business or offer complementary products which can be integrated with our products.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S1	As we develop and bring to market new software products and service offerings, we may begin competing with companies with which we have not previously competed.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S2	Further, as we expand the geographic markets into which we sell our software solutions and related services, or increase our penetration therein, we may expect to increasingly compete with companies with which we have not previously competed.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S3	It is also possible that new competitors will enter the market or that our competitors will form alliances, including alliances with Microsoft, that may enable them to rapidly increase their market share.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S4	Microsoft has not agreed to any exclusive arrangement with us, nor has it agreed not to compete with us.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P49_S5	Microsoft may decide to bring more of the core embedded development services and expertise that we provide in-house, possibly resulting in reduced software and service revenue opportunities for us.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P50_S0	The barrier to entering the market as a provider of Microsoft-based smart connected systems software and services is low.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P50_S1	In addition, Microsoft has created marketing programs to encourage systems integrators to work on Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating system software and services.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P50_S2	These systems integrators are given substantially the same access by Microsoft to the Microsoft technology as we are.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P50_S3	New competitors may have lower overhead than we do and may be able to undercut our pricing.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P50_S4	We expect that competition will increase as other established and emerging companies enter the connected device market, and as new products and technologies are introduced.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S0	Our international operations outside of North America consist principally of operations in Taipei, Taiwan and Trowbridge, England.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S1	We have a sales and sales support office in Tokyo, Japan.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S2	Because our OEM Distribution Agreement with Microsoft for the sale of Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems (e.g. Windows Embedded Compact) has been, until relatively recently, restricted to North America, including Mexico, the majority of our revenue continues to be generated from North America.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S3	In 2014, revenue generated from customers located outside of North America was 10% of total revenue, compared to 13% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S4	The decrease in non-North American revenue in 2014 was primarily attributable to lower sales of Windows Mobile operating systems, lower service revenue and lower proprietary software sales in Asia.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P51_S5	See Item 1A, Risk Factors, and Item 7, Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations, for more information regarding our international operations.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P52_S0	The following indicates the total headcount by area:
1054721_15_ITEM1_P53_S0	Of the total headcount of 197 at December 31, 2014, 112 were located in North America, 47 in Taiwan, 36 in the United Kingdom and 2 in Japan.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P54_S0	As conditions necessitate, engineering service employees perform research and development activities and vice versa.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P55_S0	In October 2013, we effected a headcount reduction that impacted approximately 20% of our worldwide workforce.
1054721_15_ITEM1_P56_S0	In general, we strive to protect our intellectual property rights through patent, copyright, trademark and trade secret laws and through contractual arrangements.
