1054721_15_ITEM7_P30_S1	We accrue bonuses and recognize the resulting expense when the bonus is judged to be reasonably likely to be earned as of year-end and is estimable.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P30_S2	The amount accrued, and expense recognized, is the estimated portion of the bonus earned on a year-to-date basis less any amounts previously accrued.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P30_S3	These estimates, judgments and assumptions are made quarterly based on available information and take into consideration our year-to-date actual results and expected results for the remainder of the year.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P30_S4	Because we consider estimated future results in assessing the likelihood of attainment, significant judgment is required.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P30_S5	If actual results differ materially from our estimates, the amount of bonus expense recorded in a particular quarter could be significantly over or under estimated.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	Taxes As part of the process of preparing our consolidated financial statements, we are required to estimate income taxes in each of the countries and other jurisdictions in which we operate.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	This process involves estimating our current tax expense together with assessing temporary differences resulting from the differing treatment of items for tax and accounting purposes.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S2	These differences result in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S3	Net operating losses and tax credits, to the extent not already utilized to offset taxable income or income taxes, also give rise to deferred tax assets.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S4	We must then assess the likelihood that any deferred tax assets will be realized from future taxable income, and, to the extent we believe that recovery is not likely, we must establish a valuation allowance.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P31_S5	Significant judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes, deferred tax assets and liabilities and any valuation allowance recorded against our deferred tax assets.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	We estimate the valuation allowance related to our deferred tax assets on a quarterly basis.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P32_S1	Our sales may be subject to other taxes, particularly withholding taxes, due to our sales to customers in countries other than the United States.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P32_S2	The tax regulations governing withholding taxes are complex, causing us to have to make assumptions about the appropriate tax treatment.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P32_S3	Further, we make sales in many jurisdictions across the United States, where tax regulations are varied and complex.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P32_S4	We must therefore continue to analyze our state tax exposure and determine what the appropriate tax treatments are, and make estimates for sales, franchise, income and other state taxes.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	The following table presents certain financial data as a percentage of total revenue for the periods indicated.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	Our historical operating results are not necessarily indicative of the results for any future period.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	Our revenue is generated from the sale of software, both our own proprietary software and third-party software that we resell, and the sale of engineering services.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	Total revenue increased $3.8 million, or 4%, to $95.9 million in 2014 from $92.1 million in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S2	This increase was driven by higher sales of Windows Embedded operating systems, and an increase in engineering services revenue, partially offset by a decline in proprietary software revenue.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S3	One customer, Future Electronics, Inc. accounted for 12% of total revenues in 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S4	No other customers accounted for 10% or more of total revenue in either 2014 or 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S5	Revenue from our customers outside of North America decreased $1.7 million, or 14%, to $10.0 million in 2014, from $11.7 million in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S6	Revenue from our customers outside of North America represented 10% of our total revenue in 2014, compared to 13% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P35_S7	The decrease in non-North American revenue in 2014 was primarily attributable to lower sales of Windows Mobile operating systems in Asia, lower engineering services revenue and lower proprietary software sales in Asia .
1054721_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Software revenue Software revenue consists of sales of third-party software and revenue realized from our own proprietary software products, which include software license sales, royalties from our software products, support and maintenance revenue, and royalties from certain engineering service contracts.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	Software revenue for 2014 and 2013 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	The vast majority of our third-party software revenue is comprised of sales of Microsoft Embedded software and Windows Mobile operating systems.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P37_S1	Third-party software revenue increased $3.0 million, or 4%, in 2014 compared to the prior year.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	increase in third-party software revenue was driven primarily by an increase in Microsoft Windows Embedded software sales as well two significant sales of our new MobileV products totaling $1.0 million, partially offset by decreases in Windows Mobile sales as well as sales of Adobe Flash which had a significant sale in Q4 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	Proprietary software revenue decreased $0.2 million, or 8%, in 2014 compared to 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	This was driven by the continued decline in sales of legacy products.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P38_S3	Service revenue Service revenue for 2014 and 2013 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	Service revenue increased $1.0 million, or 5%, in 2014 compared to the prior year.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	This increase was due to increases in service revenue generated in both Asia and EMEA offset partially by a decline in North America service revenue.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	The increase in Asia was driven by the completion of two large handheld programs.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S3	Both programs were accounted for under the zero profit percentage of completion accounting method in which we recognized revenue during the project equal to our cost and recognize the remaining revenue, equal to the gross profit on the program, at completion.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S4	One of the programs was completed during the three months ended June 30, 2014 while the other was completed during the three months ended December 31, 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S5	The decrease in North America service revenue was driven largely by a $1.7 million decrease associated with the MyFord Touch Program offset partially by increases from our existing customer base and the acquisition of new customers.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S6	Microsoft became our largest engineering services customer during the first quarter of 2012, replacing Ford Motor Company ( Ford ), as Microsoft replaced Ford as the invoiced customer on the MyFord Touch program.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S7	We continue to work on the MyFord Touch, a project we began with Ford during the second quarter of 2008; however, we now conduct these services through an agreement with Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S8	During the initial project with Ford, we provided hardware design and implementation, platform level software development, application level software development, quality assurance services and systems integration services.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P39_S9	The project has transitioned since the initial project such that we are now primarily focused on developing and integrating new user applications for the MyFord Touch, enhancing existing applications and customizing the MyFord Touch platform for additional vehicle models.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	The MyFord Touch program contributed $2.8 million in service revenue in 2014 compared to $4.5 million in 2013, representing a decline of $1.7 million or 38%.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	The decrease is attributable to a reduction in the number of engineers working on the MyFord Touch project as the amount of work on the increasingly mature platform has declined.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	In December 2014, Ford introduced Sync 3, the next generation MyFord Touch program that is scheduled to be deployed on cars in 2016 and will be based on QNX software from Blackberry instead of software from Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	While we expect to be actively involved in current generation MyFord Touch projects with Microsoft, Ford and Elektrobit through 2015 and beyond, we expect our role on MyFord Touch will be scaled back or eliminated because of the transition to QNX software for the next generation Sync 3 and our revenue and resulting gross profit will decline accordingly.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S0	Gross profit and gross margin Cost of software revenue consists primarily of the cost of third-party software products payable to third-party vendors and support costs associated with our proprietary software products.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S1	Cost of service revenue consists primarily of salaries and benefits, contractor costs and re-billable expenses, related facilities and depreciation costs, and amortization of certain intangible assets related to acquisitions.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S2	Gross profit on the sale of third-party software products is also positively impacted by rebate credits we receive from Microsoft for embedded software sales earned through the achievement of defined objectives.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S3	Prior to the third quarter of 2013, the earned rebate amount was treated as a reduction in software cost of sales in the quarter earned.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S4	Beginning in the third quarter of 2013, as a result of program modifications, we began treating a portion of the rebate as marketing development funds which are accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S5	Under this rebate program, we recognized $298,000 of rebate credits in 2014 and $744,000 in 2013, which were treated as reductions in cost of sales.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P41_S6	Additionally, during 2014 we qualified for $685,000 in rebate credits which will be accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified expenditures are made.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	The following table outlines software, services and total gross profit (dollars in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	Software gross profit and gross margin Software gross profit decreased by $1.2 million, or 9%, in 2014 compared to 2013, while software gross margin decreased by three percentage points from 18% in 2013 to 15% in 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S1	Third-party software gross margin was 14% in 2014, compared to 16% in 2013 driven primarily by a heavier concentration of sales of the lower margin product line of Microsoft Embedded software and lower rebates in 2014, as well as a large Adobe Flash sale in the fourth quarter of 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S2	Proprietary software gross margin was 75% in 2014 compared to 66% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S3	Although proprietary software revenue decreased by 8%, margins improved as a result of a decrease in the relatively fixed software cost of sales due in part to the cost reductions in the fourth quarter of 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S4	Service gross profit and gross margin Service gross profit increased $2.7 million, or 132%, in 2014 compared to 2013 driven by a $1.0 million increase in service revenue combined with a $1.7 million decrease in service cost of sales.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S5	Service gross margin was 24% in 2014, a 13 percentage point increase from 11% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S6	The decrease in service cost of sales was driven primarily by an improvement in utilization made possible by our cost reduction effort in the fourth quarter of 2013 to better align our service cost base with anticipated revenue which included the closure of our Beijing, China delivery center.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S7	Service gross profit also benefited from the recognition of $478,000 of gross profit on the previously mentioned service project completed in Japan in the second quarter of 2014 as well as the $598,000 of gross profit on the other previously mentioned service project completed in Japan in the fourth quarter of 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P43_S8	These two completed projects, with recognized profit in 2014, added approximately 2% to the reported 2014 gross margin with a similar reduction in 2013 margins.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S0	Operating expenses Selling, general and administrative Selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of salaries and related benefits, commissions and bonuses for our sales, marketing and administrative personnel and related facilities and depreciation costs, as well as professional services fees (e.g., consulting, legal, audit and tax).
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S1	Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased $3.0 million, or 20%, to $12.4 million in 2014, from $15.4 million in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S2	The decrease was driven by our cost reduction effort in the fourth quarter of 2013 as well as severance and related costs associated with the departure of our former Chief Executive Officer in September 2013 and the departure of our former Senior Vice President of Worldwide Sales and Marketing in December 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S3	Selling, general and administrative expenses represented 13% of our total revenue in 2014 compared to 17% of revenue in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S4	Research and development Research and development expenses consist primarily of salaries and benefits for software development and quality assurance personnel, contractor and consultant costs and related facilities and depreciation costs.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S5	Research and development expenses decreased $1.1 million, or 39%, to $1.7 million in 2014, from $2.8 million in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S6	The decrease was driven largely by our cost reduction efforts in the fourth quarter of 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P44_S7	Research and development expenses represented 2% of total revenue in 2014 and 3% in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P45_S0	Other income (expense), net Other income (expense) consists of interest income on our cash and investments, gains and losses we may recognize on our investments, gains or losses on foreign exchange transactions and other items.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P45_S1	Net other expense was $101,000 in 2014 compared to net other income of $40,000 in 2013, representing a decrease of $141,000.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P45_S2	This change was driven primarily by losses on foreign currency transactions in 2014 compared to gains on such transactions in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S0	Income taxes Income tax expense was $38,000 in 2014, based on income before income taxes of $2.4 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	Our effective tax rate in 2014 was 1.6%, which is below the statutory rate of 34%, primarily due to the full valuation allowance on U.S. deferred tax assets.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	Income tax expense was $2.2 million in 2013, based on loss before income taxes of $3.1 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S3	Although we recognized a loss before income taxes in 2013, we did not recognize a tax benefit due to an income tax charge in the third quarter of 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S4	We determined that it was not more likely than not that we would generate sufficient future taxable income to use our U.S. deferred tax assets.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S5	As a result, we increased our deferred tax asset valuation allowance by $2.2 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S6	Deferred tax assets relative to our foreign jurisdictions were not affected.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S7	The factors we considered in recording a full valuation allowance on our US deferred tax assets included, among other things, our recent history of losses and the uncertainty regarding generation of future taxable income.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S8	Restructuring During the fourth quarter of 2013, we effected a restructuring that included a workforce reduction and the closure of our offices in Beijing, China and Munich, Germany.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S9	The workforce reduction impacted approximately 20% of our worldwide workforce.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S10	The restructuring was intended to better align our organizational structure with our strategic focus.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S11	The staff reductions and office closures were substantially completed by the end of the fourth quarter of 2013 with some activities, including completing certain legal entity closures, continuing into early 2015.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S12	The results of this restructuring and associated asset impairment were recorded within loss from operations on our Consolidated Statement of Operations and Comprehensive Income (Loss) .
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S13	See Note 12: 2013 Restructuring in our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further information.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S14	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2014, we had $26.6 million of cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash, compared to $21.1 million at December 31, 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S15	Of these amounts, $13.1 million and $13.5 million were classified as cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013, respectively, Restricted cash is classified as long term and was $250,000 at both December 31, 2014 and 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S16	This cash is restricted under the terms of our headquarters operating lease which will continue to secure that obligation through its expiration in 2020.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S17	Our working capital was $23.7 million at December 31, 2014, compared to $19.8 million at December 31, 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S18	Net cash provided by operating activities was $5.3 million in 2014, driven by our net income of $2.3 million, positive net working capital changes of $1.4 million and non-cash expenses of $1.6 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S19	Net cash provided by operating activities was $619,000 in 2013, driven by positive net working capital changes of $2.1 million and non-cash expenses of $3.8 million, offset by our net loss of $5.3 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S20	Net cash used by investing activities was $6.3 million in 2014, due primarily to purchases of short-term investments exceeding proceeds from maturities of short-term investments by approximately $6.0 million and fixed asset purchases of $0.3 million.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S21	Investing activities provided net cash of $3.0 million in 2013, due primarily to net proceeds of short-term investments of $2.5 million and a $625,000 reduction in restricted cash under the terms of our corporate headquarters lease amendment executed in August 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P46_S22	Financing activities generated $666,000 in 2014 and $51,000 in 2013 as a result of the exercise of employee stock options.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P47_S0	We believe that our existing cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and long-term investments will be sufficient to meet our needs for working capital and capital expenditures for at least the next 12 months.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P47_S1	Cash Commitments We have the following future or potential cash commitments:
1054721_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	In conjunction with our activities under our ODAs with Microsoft, we enter OVRP commitments with Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P48_S1	Under these OVRPs, we are provided with volume pricing on a customer-by-customer basis assuming certain minimum unit volumes are met.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P48_S2	The OVRP terms are 12 months.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P48_S3	In the event we don t meet the committed minimum unit volumes, we are obligated to pay the difference between the committed per-unit volume rate and the actual per-unit rate we achieved based upon actual units purchased.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P48_S4	The OVRP arrangements do not equate to a minimum purchase commitment but rather, the arrangements are a volume pricing arrangement based upon actual volume purchased.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P49_S0	to the amounts we would subsequently owe to Microsoft if such OVRP volumes are not met.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P49_S1	However, in the event a customer is unwilling or unable to pay us, we would be negatively impacted.
1054721_15_ITEM7_P49_S2	Based upon the credit-worthiness of our customers, our historical OVRP experience with our customers and OVRP arrangements in general, we do not believe we will incur any material liability in the current or future periods.
1054721_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of BSQUARE Corporation (the Corporation ) as of December 31, 2014 and 2013, and the related consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive income (loss), shareholders equity and cash flows for the years then ended.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P0_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Corporation s management.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P1_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1054721_15_ITEM8_P1_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P1_S2	The Corporation is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P1_S3	Our audit included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Corporation s internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P1_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall consolidated financial statement presentation.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P2_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P3_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of BSQUARE Corporation as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , and the consolidated results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P4_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P5_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P6_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P7_S0	See notes to consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P8_S0	Description of Business BSQUARE Corporation ( Bsquare ) was incorporated in Washington State in July 1994.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P8_S1	We provide software solutions and related engineering services to companies that develop smart, connected systems.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S0	A smart, connected system is a dedicated purpose computing device that typically has a display, runs an operating system (e.g., Microsoft Windows CE) and is usually connected to a network or data cloud via a wired or wireless connection.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S1	Examples of smart, connected systems include set-top boxes, home gateways, point-of-sale terminals, kiosks, voting machines, gaming platforms, tablets, handheld data collection devices, personal media players, smart phones, smart vending machines and in-vehicle telematics and entertainment devices.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S2	We focus on smart, connected systems that utilize Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems as well as devices running other popular operating systems such as Android, Linux, and QNX.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S3	We have been providing software solutions for smart, connected systems since our inception.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S4	Our customers include world class original equipment manufacturers ( OEMs ), original design manufacturers ( ODMs ) and corporate enterprises ( Enterprises ), as well as silicon vendors ( SVs ) and peripheral vendors which purchase our software solutions for purposes of facilitating processor and peripheral sales.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S5	In the case of Enterprises, our customers include those which develop, market and distribute smart, connected systems on their own behalf as well as those that purchase systems from OEMs or ODMs and require additional software, integration and/or testing.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P9_S6	The software solutions we provide are utilized and deployed throughout various phases of our customers device life cycle, including design, development, customization, quality assurance and deployment.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P10_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of BSQUARE Corporation and our wholly owned subsidiaries.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P10_S1	All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P11_S0	Use of Estimates Preparing financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P11_S1	Examples include provisions for bad debts and income taxes, estimates of progress on professional engineering service arrangements, bonus accruals, fair value of intangible assets and property and equipment, fair values of stock-based awards and the fair values of acquired assets and liabilities, among other estimates.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P11_S2	Actual results may differ from these estimates.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S0	Basic income or loss per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period, and excludes any dilutive effects of common stock equivalent shares, such as options, restricted stock awards, restricted stock units and warrants.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S1	Restricted stock awards ( RSAs ) are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income or loss per share when underlying restrictions expire and the awards are no longer forfeitable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S2	Restricted stock units ( RSUs ) are considered outstanding and included in the computation of basic income or loss per share only when vested.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S3	Diluted income per share is computed using the weighted average number of common shares outstanding and common stock equivalent shares outstanding during the period using the treasury stock method.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S4	Common stock equivalent shares are excluded from the computation if their effect is anti-dilutive.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P12_S5	Unvested but outstanding RSUs and RSAs (which are forfeitable) are included in the diluted income per share calculation.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P13_S0	In a period where we are in a net loss position, the diluted loss per share is computed using the basic share count.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P13_S1	The following table presents a reconciliation of the number of shares used in the calculation of basic and diluted income (loss) per share (in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM8_P14_S0	Common stock equivalent shares of 901,069 and 990,831 were excluded from the computations of basic and diluted income per share for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, because their effect was anti-dilutive.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S0	Cash, Cash Equivalents and Investments We invest our excess cash primarily in highly liquid debt instruments of U.S. government agencies and municipalities, debt instruments issued by foreign governments, corporate commercial paper, money market funds, and corporate debt securities.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S1	We classify all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of three months or less from date of purchase as cash equivalents and all highly liquid investments with stated maturities of greater than three months as short-term investments.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S2	Short-term investments consist entirely of marketable securities which are all classified as available-for-sale securities and are recorded at their estimated fair value.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S3	We determine the appropriate classification of our investments at the time of purchase and reevaluate such designation at each balance sheet date.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S4	We may or may not hold securities with stated maturities greater than 12 months until maturity.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S5	As we view these securities as available to support current operations, we classify securities with maturities beyond 12 months as short-term investments.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P15_S6	We carry these securities at fair value, and report the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, as a component of stockholders equity, except for unrealized losses determined to be other than temporary which are recorded in other expense.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P16_S0	Restricted Cash Our restricted cash represents funds held at a financial institution as security for an outstanding letter of credit expiring in 2020 related to our corporate headquarters lease obligation.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P17_S0	Financial Instruments and Concentrations of Risk Financial instruments that potentially subject us to concentrations of credit risk consist principally of cash equivalents, short-term investments, and accounts receivable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P18_S0	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts We record accounts receivable at the invoiced amount net of an estimated allowance for doubtful accounts to reserve for potentially uncollectible receivables.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P18_S1	We review customers which are past due to identify specific customers with known disputes or collectability issues.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P18_S2	In determining the amount of the allowance, we make judgments about the creditworthiness of significant customers based on ongoing credit evaluations.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P19_S0	Equipment, Furniture and Leasehold Improvements We account for equipment, furniture and leasehold improvements at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P19_S1	We compute depreciation of equipment and furniture using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets, generally three years.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P20_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized using the straight-line method over the shorter of the lease term or estimated useful lives, ranging from two to ten years.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P20_S1	Maintenance and repairs costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P21_S0	When assets are retired or otherwise disposed of, gains or losses are included in the statement of operations.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P22_S0	When facts and circumstances indicate that the value of long-lived assets may be impaired, an evaluation of recoverability is performed by comparing the carrying value of the asset to projected undiscounted future cash flows.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P22_S1	Upon indication that the carrying value of such assets may not be recoverable, we recognize an impairment loss as a charge against current operations based on the difference between the carrying value of the asset and its fair value.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P23_S0	Intangible Assets Intangible assets were recorded as a result of business acquisitions and are stated at estimated fair value at the time of acquisition less accumulated amortization.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P24_S0	We amortize our acquired intangible assets using the straight-line method using lives ranging from one to ten years.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P25_S0	We review intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P25_S1	We measure recoverability of these assets by comparing the carrying amounts to the future undiscounted cash flows the assets are expected to generate.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P26_S0	If intangible assets are considered to be impaired, the impairment to be recognized equals the amount by which the carrying value of the asset exceeds its fair market value.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P27_S0	Goodwill We evaluate goodwill for impairment annually or more frequently when an event occurs or circumstances change that indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P27_S1	We test goodwill for impairment by performing a qualitative assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying amount.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P27_S2	If it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is greater than the carrying amount, no further testing is performed.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P28_S0	If it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the carrying amount, we perform a quantitative two-step impairment test.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P29_S0	step compares the fair value of the reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P29_S1	If the carrying amount exceeds fair value, then the second step of the impairment test is performed to measure the amount of any impairment loss.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P30_S0	We record all fees payable and accrued liabilities related to the sale of third-party software, such as Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems, as third-party software fees payable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P31_S0	Research and Development Research and development costs are expensed as incurred.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P32_S0	Advertising Costs All costs of advertising, including cooperative marketing arrangements, are expensed as incurred.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P32_S1	Advertising expense was $558,000 in 2014 and $501,000 in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P33_S0	The estimated fair value of stock based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P34_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P34_S1	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of our common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P34_S2	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P34_S3	The BSM model requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P34_S4	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P35_S0	Comprehensive Income (Loss) Comprehensive income (loss) refers to net income (loss) and other revenue, expenses, gains and losses that, under generally accepted accounting principles, are recorded as an element of shareholders equity but are excluded from the calculation of net income (loss).
1054721_15_ITEM8_P36_S0	Income Taxes We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and certain foreign jurisdictions.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P36_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P37_S0	We compute income taxes using the asset and liability method, under which deferred income taxes are provided for on the temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and the tax basis of our assets and liabilities.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P37_S1	Our deferred tax amounts are measured using currently enacted tax rates that are expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P37_S2	A valuation allowance is established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P38_S0	We recognize tax benefits from an uncertain position only if it is more likely than not that the position is sustainable, based on its technical merits.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P38_S1	The tax benefit of a qualifying position is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than fifty percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement with a taxing authority having full knowledge of all relevant information.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P38_S2	Interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions are classified in the consolidated financial statements as income tax expense.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P39_S0	The functional currency of foreign subsidiaries is their local currency.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P39_S1	Accordingly, assets and liabilities are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P39_S2	Resulting translation adjustments are included in Other Comprehensive Income (Loss) and Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss , a separate component of shareholders equity.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P40_S0	The net gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are recorded in the period incurred and were not significant for any of the periods presented.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P41_S0	Revenue Recognition We recognize revenue from software and engineering service sales when the following four revenue recognition criteria are met: persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists; delivery has occurred or services have been rendered; the selling price is fixed or determinable; and collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P41_S1	Contracts and customer purchase orders are generally used to determine the existence of an arrangement.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P41_S2	Shipping documents and time records are generally used to verify delivery.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P41_S3	We assess whether the selling price is fixed or determinable based on the contract and/or customer purchase order and payment terms associated with the transaction and whether the sales price is subject to refund or adjustment.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P42_S0	creditworthiness of the customer as determined by credit checks and analysis, as well as the customer s payment history.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P43_S0	Periodically, we will begin work on engineering service engagements prior to having a signed contract and, in some cases, the contract is signed in a quarter after which service delivery costs are incurred.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P43_S1	We do not defer costs associated with such engagements before we have received a signed contract.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P43_S2	We recognize software revenue upon shipment provided that no significant obligations remain on our part, substantive acceptance conditions, if any, have been met and the other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P44_S0	Service revenue from time and materials contracts, and training service agreements, is recognized as services are performed.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P44_S1	Fixed-price service agreements, and certain time and materials service agreements with capped fee structures, are accounted for using the percentage-of-completion method assuming reasonable estimates of completion can be made.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P45_S0	We use the percentage-of-completion method of accounting because we believe it is the most accurate method to recognize revenue based on the nature and scope of these engineering service contracts; we believe it is a better measure of periodic income results than other methods and it better matches revenue recognized with the costs incurred.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P45_S1	Percentage of completion is measured based primarily on input measures such as hours incurred to date compared to total estimated hours to complete, with consideration given to output measures, such as contract milestones, when applicable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P45_S2	Significant judgment is required when estimating total hours and progress to completion on these arrangements which determines the amount of revenue we recognize as well as whether a loss is recognized if one is expected to be incurred for the remainder of the project.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P46_S0	Revisions to hour and cost estimates are incorporated in the period in which the facts that give rise to the revision become known.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P47_S0	In certain situations when it is impractical for us to reliably estimate either specific amounts or ranges of contract revenues and costs, and where we anticipate that we will not incur a loss, a zero profit model is used for revenue recognition.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P47_S1	Equal amounts of revenue and cost are recognized during the contract period, and profit is recognized when the project is completed and accepted.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P47_S2	This method was used in 2013 and 2014 for two engineering service contracts in Japan.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P48_S0	We also enter into arrangements in which a customer purchases a combination of software licenses, engineering services and post-contract customer support and/or maintenance ( PCS ).
1054721_15_ITEM8_P48_S1	As a result, judgment is sometimes required to determine the appropriate accounting, including how the price should be allocated among the deliverable elements if there are multiple elements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P49_S0	PCS may include rights to upgrades, when and if available, telephone support, updates and enhancements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P50_S0	When vendor specific objective evidence ( VSOE ) of fair value exists for all elements in a multiple element arrangement, revenue is allocated to each element based on the relative fair value of each of the elements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P50_S1	VSOE of fair value is established by the price charged when the same element is sold separately.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P50_S2	Accordingly, the judgments involved in assessing the fair values of various elements of an agreement can impact the recognition of revenue in each period.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P50_S3	Changes in the allocation of the sales price between deliverables might impact the timing of revenue recognition, but would not change the total revenue recognized on the contract.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P51_S0	When elements such as software and engineering services are contained in a single arrangement, or in related arrangements with the same customer, we allocate revenue to each element based on its relative fair value, provided that such element meets the criteria for treatment as a separate unit of accounting.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P51_S1	In the absence of fair value for a delivered element, revenue is first allocated to the fair value of the undelivered elements and then allocated to the residual delivered elements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P51_S2	In the absence of fair value for an undelivered element, the arrangement is accounted for as a single unit of accounting, resulting in a delay of revenue recognition for the delivered elements until the undelivered elements are fulfilled.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P52_S0	When engineering services and royalties are contained in a single arrangement, we recognize revenue from engineering services as earned in accordance with the criteria above even though the effective rate per hour may be lower than typical because the customer is contractually obligated to pay royalties on their device shipments.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P52_S1	We recognize royalty revenue, classified as software revenue, when the royalty report from the customer is received or when such royalties are contractually guaranteed and the other revenue recognition criteria are met, particularly the criteria that collectability is reasonably assured.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P53_S0	No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers , amending revenue recognition guidance and requiring more detailed disclosures to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing, and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P53_S1	The guidance is effective for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2016, with early adoption prohibited.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P53_S2	We are currently evaluating the impact this ASU may have on our consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P54_S0	In June 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-12, Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Accounting for Share-Based Payments When the Terms of an Award Provide That a Performance Target Could Be Achieved after the Requisite Service Period.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P54_S1	The new guidance requires that a performance target that affects vesting and that could be achieved after the requisite service period is treated as a performance condition.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P54_S2	As such, the performance target should not be reflected in estimating the grant date fair value of the award.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P54_S3	The guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2015, with early adoption permitted.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P54_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this guidance to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P55_S0	In August 2014 the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-15, Disclosure of Uncertainties about an Entity s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern, requiring management to evaluate whether there is a substantial doubt about an entity s ability to continue as a going concern and to provide related disclosures in the notes to the financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P55_S1	The new guidance reduces diversity in the timing and content of disclosures from current guidance, and is effective for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2015 with early adoption permitted.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P55_S2	We do not expect the adoption of this guidance to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P56_S0	In January 2015 the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-01, Income Statement Extraordinary and Unusual Items, eliminating the concept of an extraordinary item from U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
1054721_15_ITEM8_P56_S1	As a result, an entity will no longer be required to segregate extraordinary items from the results of ordinary operations, to separately present an extraordinary item on its income statement, net of tax, after income from continuing operations or to disclose income taxes and earnings-per-share data applicable to an extraordinary item.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P56_S2	However, ASU 2015-01 retains the presentation and disclosure guidance for items that are unusual in nature and occur infrequently.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P56_S3	The new guidance will be effective for annual and interim reporting periods beginning after December 1, 2016.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P56_S4	We do not expect the adoption of this guidance to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P57_S0	Cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments, and restricted cash consist of the following (in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM8_P58_S0	Gross unrealized gains and losses on our cash equivalents and short-term investments were not material as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P58_S1	Our restricted cash balance at December 31, 2014 and 2013 relates to a letter of credit securing the lease of our corporate headquarters.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P59_S0	We measure our cash equivalents, marketable securities and restricted cash at fair value.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P60_S0	Fair value is an exit price, representing the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P60_S1	As such, fair value is a market-based measurement that should be determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or a liability.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P60_S2	A three-tier fair value hierarchy is established as a basis for considering such assumptions and for inputs used in the valuation methodologies in measuring fair value:
1054721_15_ITEM8_P61_S0	Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P62_S0	Directly or indirectly observable market-based inputs or unobservable inputs used in models or other valuation methodologies.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P63_S0	Unobservable inputs that are not corroborated by market data.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P63_S1	The inputs require significant management judgment or estimation.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P64_S0	We classify our cash equivalents, marketable securities and restricted cash within Level 1 or Level 2.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P64_S1	This is because we value these items using quoted market prices or alternative pricing sources and models utilizing market observable inputs that are actively quoted and can be validated through external sources, including third-party pricing services, brokers and market transactions.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P64_S2	We review the pricing techniques and methodologies of the independent pricing service for Level 2 investments and believe that the policies adequately consider market activity, either based on specific transactions for the security valued or based on modeling of securities with similar credit quality, duration, yield and structure that were recently traded.

1054721_15_ITEM8_P77_S0	As of December 31, 2014, our deferred tax assets were primarily the result of U.S. net operating loss and R D credit carryforwards.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P77_S1	Valuation allowances of $26.8 million and $27.7 million have been recorded against our gross deferred tax asset balance as of December 31, 2014, and December 31, 2013, respectively.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P78_S0	The provision for income taxes differs from the amount of expected income tax expense (benefit) determined by applying the applicable U.S. statutory federal income tax rate to pre-tax income (loss), as a result of the following (in thousands, except percentages):
1054721_15_ITEM8_P79_S0	At December 31, 2014, we had approximately $59.7 million of federal and $3.4 million of state net operating loss carryforwards, which have begun to expire, including $0.3 million of state losses which will expire in 2015.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P79_S1	Of the federal net operating loss carryforwards, an aggregate of $41.8 million will expire in 2022 and 2023.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P79_S2	We also have $2.7 million of Research and Development ( R D ) credit carryforwards, which begin to expire in 2018.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P79_S3	Use of these carryforwards may subject us to an annual limitation due to Section 382 of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code which restricts the ability of a corporation that undergoes an ownership change to use its carryforwards.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P80_S0	Under the applicable tax rules, an ownership change occurs if holders of more than five percent of an issuer s outstanding common stock, collectively, increase their ownership percentage by more than 50 percentage points over a rolling three-year period.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P80_S1	We periodically perform analyses of possible ownership changes, including consideration of third party studies, and do not believe that an ownership change of more than 50 percentage points has occurred based upon the latest study completed as of December 31, 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P80_S2	We have evaluated all the material income tax positions taken on our income tax filings to various tax authorities, and we determined that we did not have unrealized tax benefits related to uncertain tax positions recorded at December 31, 2014 or 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P80_S3	Because of net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards, substantially all of our tax years remain open and subject to examination.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S0	Contingencies A third party software vendor has invoiced us a total of $934,000 for certain licensed software that was lost in transit by a common carrier.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S1	Although these licenses have been deactivated and there is no indication of counterfeit use, the vendor has asserted that we are financially responsible for these lost licenses and therefore must pay the full royalty value.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S2	We believe that we have contractual defenses and insurance that would cover losses in excess of $100,000.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S3	We have accrued a liability of $100,000, but have made no provision for losses in excess of this amount since we do not believe that this liability is probable.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S4	Our commitments include obligations outstanding under operating leases, which expire through 2020.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S5	We have lease commitments for office space in Bellevue, Washington; Taipei, Taiwan; Trowbridge, UK; and Tokyo, Japan.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S6	We also lease office space on a month-to-month basis in Akron, Ohio, San Diego, California and Boston, Massachusetts.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S7	In August 2013, we amended the lease agreement for our Bellevue, Washington headquarters and extended the term of the original lease that was scheduled to expire in August 2014 to May 2020.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S8	Rent expense was $1.2 million in 2014 and $1.6 million in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S9	As of December 31, 2014, we had $250,000 pledged as collateral for a bank letter of credit under the terms of our headquarters facility lease.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P81_S10	The pledged cash supporting the outstanding letter of credit is recorded as restricted cash.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P82_S0	Operating lease commitments at December 31, 2014 are as follows (in thousands):
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S0	Volume Pricing Agreements In conjunction with our activities under the OEM Distribution Agreements ( ODAs ) with Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ), we enter into OEM Volume Royalty Pricing ( OVRP ) commitments with Microsoft.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S1	Under these OVRPs, we are provided with volume pricing on a customer-by-customer basis assuming certain minimum unit volumes are met.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S2	The OVRP terms are 12 months.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S3	In the event we don t meet the committed minimum unit volumes, we are obligated to pay the difference between the committed per-unit volume rate and the actual per-unit rate we achieved based upon actual units purchased.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S4	The OVRP arrangements do not equate to a minimum purchase commitment but rather, the arrangements are a volume pricing arrangement based upon actual volume purchased.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S5	In substantially all instances, we have reciprocal agreements with our customers such that we will receive per-unit price adjustments, similar to the amounts we would subsequently owe to Microsoft if such OVRP volumes are not met.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S6	However, in the event a customer is unwilling or unable to pay us, we would be negatively impacted.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P83_S7	Based upon the credit-worthiness of our customers, our historical OVRP experience with our customers and OVRP arrangements in general, we do not believe we will incur any material liability in the current or future periods relating to existing agreements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S0	Equity Compensation Plans We have a stock plan (the Stock Plan ) and an inducement stock plan for newly hired employees (the Inducement Plan ) (collectively the Plans ).
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S1	Under the Plans, stock options may be granted with a fixed exercise price that is equivalent to fair market value on the date of grant.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S2	These options have a term of up to 10 years and vest over a predetermined period, generally four years.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S3	Incentive stock options granted under the Stock Plan may only be granted to our employees.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S4	The Plans also allow for awards of non-qualified stock options, stock appreciation rights, RSAs and unrestricted stock awards, and RSUs.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P84_S5	The estimated fair value of stock-based awards is recognized as compensation expense over the vesting period of the award, net of estimated forfeitures.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P85_S0	We estimate forfeitures of stock based awards based on historical experience and expected future activity.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P86_S0	The fair value of restricted stock awards and restricted stock units is determined based on the number of shares granted and the quoted price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P86_S1	The fair value of stock option awards are estimated at the grant date based on the fair value of each vesting tranche as calculated by the Black-Scholes-Merton ( BSM ) option-pricing model.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P86_S2	The BSM model requires various highly judgmental assumptions including expected volatility and option life.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P86_S3	If any of the assumptions used in the BSM model change significantly, stock-based compensation expense may differ materially in the future from that recorded in the current period.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P87_S0	The fair values of our equity awards, primarily stock option grants, were estimated with the following weighted average assumptions:

1054721_15_ITEM8_P90_S1	This cost will be amortized on the straight-line method over a weighted-average period of approximately 1.2 years.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P91_S0	The aggregate intrinsic value represents the difference between the exercise price of the underlying options and the quoted price of our common stock for the number of options that were in-the-money at year end.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P92_S0	We issue new shares of common stock upon exercise of stock options.

1054721_15_ITEM8_P96_S0	We have a Profit Sharing and Deferred Compensation Plan, The Bsquare Corporation 401(k) Plan and Trust, (the Profit Sharing Plan ) under Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P97_S0	Substantially all full-time employees are eligible to participate in the Profit Sharing Plan.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P97_S1	We typically elect to match the participants contributions to the Profit Sharing Plan up to a certain amount subject to vesting.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P97_S2	Participants will receive their share of the value of their investments, and any applicable vested match, upon retirement or termination.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P97_S3	We made matching contributions of $243,000 in 2014 and $335,000 in 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P97_S4	Of the annual matching contributions, $114,000 of the 2014 and zero of the 2013 contributions were composed of transfers from the Profit Sharing Plan s forfeiture account.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S0	Significant Customer One customer, Future Electronics, Inc. accounted for 12% of total revenues in 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S1	No other customers accounted for 10% or more of total revenue in either 2014 or 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S2	Future Electronics, Inc. had an accounts receivable balance of $3.7 million, or 23% of total accounts receivable, as of December 31, 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S3	Mitsubishi Electric Corporation had an accounts receivable balance of $2.8 million, or 18% of total accounts receivable, as of December 31, 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S4	Each of these balances was subsequently collected.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P98_S5	No other customer accounted for 10% or more of total accounts receivable at December 31, 2014 or 2013.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P99_S0	Significant Supplier We have two ODAs with Microsoft which enable us to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems to our customers in the United States, Canada, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Mexico, Peru, Puerto Rico, the Caribbean (excluding Cuba), the European Union, the European Free Trade Association, Turkey and Africa, which expire on June 30, 2016.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P99_S1	We also have four ODAs with Microsoft which allow us to sell Microsoft Windows Mobile operating systems in the Americas (excluding Cuba), Japan, Taiwan, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, which expire on June 30, 2015.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P99_S2	Software sales under these agreements constitute a significant portion of our software revenue and total revenue.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P99_S3	These agreements are typically renewed annually or semi-annually; however, there is no automatic renewal provision in any of these agreements.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P99_S4	Further, these agreements can be terminated unilaterally by Microsoft at any time.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P100_S0	Microsoft currently offers a rebate program to sell Microsoft Windows Embedded operating systems pursuant to which we earn money for achieving certain predefined objectives.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P100_S1	Prior to the third quarter of 2013, the earned rebate amount was treated as a reduction in software cost of sales in the quarter earned.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P100_S2	Beginning in the third quarter of 2013, as a result of program modifications, we began treating a portion of the rebate as marketing development funds which are accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P100_S3	Under this rebate program, we recognized $298,000 in 2014 and $774,000 in 2013, which was treated as a reduction in cost of sales.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P100_S4	Additionally, we qualified for $685,000 in 2014 and $409,000 in 2013, in rebate credits which will be accounted for as a reduction in marketing expense if and when qualified program expenditures are made.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P101_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2013, we effected a restructuring that included a workforce reduction and the closure of our offices in Beijing, China and Munich, Germany.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P101_S1	The workforce reduction impacted approximately 20% of our worldwide workforce.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P101_S2	The restructuring was intended to better align our organizational structure with our strategic focus.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P101_S3	The staff reductions and office closures were substantially completed by the end of the fourth quarter of 2013 with some activities, including legal entity closures, continuing through 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P101_S4	We anticipate completion in early 2015.

1054721_15_ITEM8_P104_S1	There are no segment managers who are held accountable by our chief operating decision-makers, or anyone else, for operations, operating results, and planning for levels or components below the consolidated unit level.
1054721_15_ITEM8_P104_S2	Accordingly, we consider ourselves to be in a single reporting segment and operating unit structure.

1054721_15_ITEM9_P0_S0	Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure .
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures We maintain disclosure controls and procedures that are designed to ensure that the information required to be disclosed in the reports that we file or submit under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ( Exchange Act ) is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In connection with the preparation of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, our management carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as of December 31, 2014, of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as such term is defined under Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Based upon this evaluation, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S3	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S4	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial reporting and the preparation of our financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S5	Internal control over financial reporting is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) promulgated under the Exchange Act and includes those policies and procedures that: (a) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our assets; (b) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that our receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of our management and directors; and (c) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of our assets that could have a material effect on our financial statements.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S6	All internal controls, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P0_S7	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P1_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) .
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Based on its assessment, our management concluded that, as of December 31, 2014, our internal control over financial reporting was effective.
1054721_15_ITEM9A_P1_S3	Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of 2014 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1054721_15_ITEM9B_P0_S0	Effective February 17, 2015, Harel Kodesh resigned from our Board of Directors.

1054721_15_ITEM15_P7_S0	Indicates a management contract or compensatory plan or arrangement.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P8_S0	Confidential treatment has previously been granted by the SEC for certain portions of the referenced exhibit.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P9_S0	This Restricted Stock Unit Agreement (the Agreement ) is made as of [date] by and between BSQUARE CORPORATION, a Washington corporation (the Company ), and Participant s Name (the Participant ).
1054721_15_ITEM15_P10_S0	1. Award of Restricted Stock Units .
1054721_15_ITEM15_P10_S1	Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, on the date of this Agreement the company will award to Participant Restricted Stock Units representing # of units shares of Common Stock (the Units ).
1054721_15_ITEM15_P10_S2	The award of the Units shall be subject to the terms, definitions and provisions of the BSQUARE Corporation 2011 Inducement Award Plan now and as amended in the future, the Plan ) adopted by the Company, which is incorporated in this Agreement by reference.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P10_S3	Unless otherwise defined in this Agreement, the terms used in this Agreement shall have the meanings defined in the Plan.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P11_S0	No payment is required for the Units that Participant is receiving.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P12_S0	The Units shall vest as follows: Vesting terms .
1054721_15_ITEM15_P13_S0	If Participant s employment or contractual relationship with the Company terminates for any reason, then Participant s Units will be forfeited to the extent that they have not vested before the termination date and do not vest as a result of the termination.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P13_S1	This means that the Units that have not already vested will immediately be cancelled.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P13_S2	Participant will receive no payment for Units that are forfeited.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P13_S3	Unless otherwise required by applicable law, the Company determines when Participant s employment or contractual relationship with the Company terminates for this purpose.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P14_S0	other than by will, by the applicable laws of descent and distribution or pursuant to any qualified domestic relations order, and shall not be subject to execution, attachment or similar process.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P14_S1	Upon any attempt to transfer, assign, pledge, hypothecate or otherwise dispose of the Units or of any right or privilege conferred hereby contrary to the provisions hereof, or upon the sale or levy or any attachment or similar process upon the rights and privileges conferred hereby, the Units shall thereupon terminate and become null and void.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P15_S0	By accepting the Units, Participant agrees not to sell any shares of Common Stock at a time when applicable laws, Company policies or an agreement between the Company and its underwriters prohibit a sale.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P15_S1	This restriction will apply as long as Participant s employment or contractual relationship with the Company continues and for such period of time after the termination of such employment or contractual relationship as the Company may specify.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P16_S0	In the case of any stock split, stock dividend or like change in the nature of shares granted by this Agreement, the number of Units shall be proportionately adjusted as set forth in the Plan.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P17_S0	Each of Participant s Units will be settled when it vests, unless Participant and the Company have agreed to a later settlement date.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P18_S0	will receive one share of Common Stock for each vested Unit.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P18_S1	The Company, at its sole discretion, may substitute an equivalent amount of cash if the distribution of stock is not reasonably practicable due to the requirements of applicable law.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P18_S2	The amount of cash will be determined on the basis of the Fair Market Value of the Company s Common Stock at the time of settlement, as further described in the Plan.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P19_S0	The Participant acknowledges that he or she has read and understands the terms of this Agreement and the Plan, and that:
1054721_15_ITEM15_P20_S0	(d) This Agreement does not constitute an employment agreement nor does it entitle the Participant to any specific employment or to employment for a period of time and that the Participant s continued employment, if any, with the Company shall be at will and is subject to termination in accordance with the Company s prevailing policies and any other agreement between the Participant and the Company.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P21_S0	The acceptance of the Units and the sale of Common Stock issued pursuant to such Units may have consequences under federal and state tax and securities laws which may vary depending on the individual circumstances of the Participant.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P21_S1	Accordingly, the Participant acknowledges that the Participant has been advised to consult his or her personal legal and tax advisor in connection with this Agreement and the Participant s dealings with respect to the Units or the Common Stock.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P22_S0	Participant acknowledges receipt of a copy of the Plan and represents that he or she is familiar with the terms and provisions thereof, and hereby accepts the Unites and agrees to be bound by the contractual terms as set forth herein and in the Plan.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P23_S0	Participant hereby agrees to accept as binding, conclusive and final all decisions and interpretations of the Plan Administrator regarding any questions relating to the Units.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P23_S1	In the event of a conflict between the terms and provisions of the Plan and the terms and provisions of this Agreement, the Plan terms and provisions shall prevail.
1054721_15_ITEM15_P23_S2	This Agreement, including the Plan, constitutes the entire agreement between Participant and the Company on the subject matter hereof and supersedes all proposals, written or oral, and all other communications between the parties relating to such subject matter.

1054721_16_ITEM1_P0_S0	CAUTIONARY NOTE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS This Annual Report on Form 10-K contains "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the safe-harbor provisions of the U.S. Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P1_S0	Forward-looking statements can often be identified by words such as: "expect," "believe," "estimate," "plan," "strategy," "future," "potential," "continue," "may," "should," "will," and similar references to future periods.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P1_S1	Examples include, among others, statements about: expected operating results, such as revenue and earnings; anticipated levels of capital expenditures; future market conditions; our belief that we have sufficient liquidity to fund our business operations for at least the next 12 months; expectations of the effect on our financial condition of claims, litigation, contingent liabilities and supplier audits; and strategies for customer retention, growth, new product and service developments, and market position.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S0	Forward-looking statements are neither historical facts nor assurances about future performance.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S1	Instead they are only predictions, based on current beliefs, expectations and assumptions about the future of our business and other future conditions.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S2	Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and changes in circumstances that are difficult to predict and many of which are outside of our control.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S3	Actual events and results may differ materially.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S4	Therefore, you should not rely on any of these forward-looking statements.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S5	Any forward-looking statement made by us in this report is based only on information available to us on the date of this report.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S6	Except as may be required by law, we undertake no obligation to publicly update any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future developments or otherwise.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S7	Our forward-looking statements can be affected by inaccurate assumptions we might make or by known or unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S8	We discuss many of these risks, uncertainties and other factors in this Annual Report on Form 10-K in greater detail under the Item 1A Risk Factors.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S9	We caution readers that our business and financial performance are subject to substantial risks and uncertainties.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P2_S10	BUSINESS Overview As used in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, we, us , our , the Company and BSQUARE refer to BSQUARE Corporation.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	We primarily resell software from Microsoft Corporation ( Microsoft ) and provide software solutions and related engineering services to companies that develop smart, connected systems.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S0	A smart, connected system is a dedicated purpose computing device that typically has a display, runs an operating system (e.g., Microsoft Windows CE or Google Android TM platform) and is usually connected to a network or data cloud via a wired or wireless connection.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S1	Examples of smart, connected systems include set-top boxes, home gateways, point-of-sale terminals, kiosks, voting machines, gaming platforms, tablets, handheld data collection devices, personal media players, smart phones, smart vending machines, ATM machines, casino gaming machines, digital signs and in-vehicle telematics and entertainment devices.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S2	We focus on smart, connected systems that utilize various Microsoft Windows Embedded and Windows Mobile operating systems as well as devices running other popular operating systems such as Android, Linux, and QNX.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S3	We have been providing software solutions for smart, connected systems since our inception.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S4	Our customers include world class original equipment manufacturers ( OEMs ), original design manufacturers ( ODMs ) and corporate enterprises ( Enterprises ), as well as silicon vendors ( SVs ) and peripheral vendors which purchase our software solutions for purposes of facilitating processor and peripheral sales.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S5	In the case of Enterprises, our customers include those that develop, market and distribute smart, connected systems on their own behalf as well as those that purchase systems from OEMs or ODMs and require additional software, integration and/or testing.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S6	The software solutions we provide are utilized and deployed throughout various phases of our customers device life cycle, including design, development, customization, quality assurance and deployment.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P4_S7	Increasingly, we are focusing on developing and offering our own products such as DataV TM to address the emerging Internet of Things ( IoT ) market, which is the interconnection of uniquely identifiable embedded computing devices within the existing internet infrastructure.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P5_S0	DataV is an actionable data solution for the IoT market that includes software products, applications and services that turn raw device data into useful, meaningful and actionable data.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P6_S0	We were incorporated in the State of Washington in July 1994.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P6_S1	Our principal office is located at 110 110th Avenue NE, Suite 300, Bellevue, Washington 98004, and our telephone number is (425) 519-5900.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P7_S0	Industry Background The increasing opportunity for connectivity and exchange of data coupled with the rise of cloud storage and cloud computing infrastructure is driving new applications for smart, connected systems of all kinds.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P8_S0	The smart, connected systems industry is characterized by a wide variety of software and hardware configurations and end-user applications, often designed to address a specific vertical market.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P8_S1	To accommodate these diverse characteristics in a cost-effective manner, OEMs, ODMs and Enterprises require operating systems and software that can support a diverse set of hardware requirements and connect to a wide variety of networks, systems, peripherals, content and applications.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P8_S2	The smart, connected systems marketplace is being influenced by the following factors:
1054721_16_ITEM1_P9_S0	Expectations for device functionality continue to grow.
1054721_16_ITEM1_P10_S0	Security is an increasingly important concern as devices are now often able to access networks and store sensitive information locally such as email, spreadsheets and other documents.
